gentlenesse shamefast maiden shamefastnesse constant hert euer businesse driue sluggardie bacchus mouth maistrie wine youth done venus encrece men fire woll casten oyle grece owne vertue vnconstrained hath full oft sicke yfained would flie companie likely treaten follie feast reuels daunces occasion daliaunces thing maken child bee soone ripe bold men may see full perillons hath yore soon may learne lore boldnesse wife ye maistresses old life lord doughters han gouernaunce ne taketh word displeasaunce think ye set gouernings lord doughters onely two thing either han kept honesty either ye han fall freelty knowen well ynough old daunce conne forsake fully mischaunce euermore therefore christ sake keepeth well tho ye vndertake theefe veneson hath forlaft likerousnesse theeues craft keepe forrest best man keepeth hem well ye woll ye looketh well vice ye assent least ye damned euill entent doth traytour certaine taketh keepe shall saine treason soueraigne pestilence wight betrayeth innocence ye father eke ye mother also though ye han child one mo charge sufferaunce while gouernaunce beth ware yt ensample liuing either negligence chastising ne perish dare well say done ye shall full sore abay vnder sheepheard soft negligent wolfe hath many sheep lambe rent sufficeth one ensample mote turne ayen matere maid tell tale expresse kept selue needed maistresse liuing maiden might rede booke euery good worke dede longeth maid vertuous prudent bounteous sprong euery side beauty bounty wide thorow ye lond preised echone loued vertue saue enuy alone sorry men wele glad sorrow vnhele doctour maketh descriptioun maid went day toun toward temple mother dere young maiden manere iustice toun gouernour regioun befell iustice eyen cast vpon maid auising full fast came foreby iudge stood anon heart chaunged mood caught beauty maid himselfe full priuely said maid shall mine man anon fiend heart ran taught suddainly wt sleight maid purpose win might certes force ne meed thought able speed strong friend eke confirmed soueraigne beaute well wist might neuer win make body sin great deliberatioun sent client toun knew full subtill full bold iudge client tale hath told secret wise made ensure tell vnto creature lese hede assented cursed rede glad iudge made good chere yaue gift precious dere shapen conspiracie fro point point letcherie performed full subtilly ye shullen heare openly home goth client yt hight claudius false iudge hight appius name fable knowen historiall thing notable sentence sooth dout false iudge say goth fast hasten delight may befell soone day false iudge telleth u storie wont sat consistorie yaue doomes vpon sundry caas false client came forth full great paas said lord doth right vpon pitous bill plaine vpon virginius woll say thus woll proue find good witnesse sooth bill woll expresse iudge answerd absence may yeue definite sentence let doe call woll gladly thou shalt haue right wrong virginius came wete ye iudges right anon rad cursed bill sentence ye shall heare lord appius deare sheweth poore seruaunt claudius knight called virginius ayenst law ayenst equite holdeth expresse ayenst seruant yt thral right mine hous stolen night while full yong woll preue witnesse lord ye greue doughter say wherefore lord iustice pray yeeld thrall lo sentence bill virginius gan upon client behold hastily ere tale told would haue defended shuld knight witnesse many trew wight false said aduersarie cursed iudge would lenger tary word virginius yaue iudgment said thus deme anon client seruaunt haue thou shalt lenger thine house saue go bring forth put ward client shal haue thrall thus award worthy knight virginius assent iudge appius must force deare doughter yeuen vnto iudge letchery liuen goth home set hall let anon deare doughter call face dead ashen cold vpon humble face gan behold father pity sticking hert would purpose conuert doughter qd virginia thy name ben two way either death shame thou must suffer ala yt borne neuer thou deseruedest whereforne dien sword knife oh dere doughter comfort life haue fostred vp plesance thou neuer remembrance doughter yt art last wo life last ioy also iemmme chastitie patience take thou thy death sentence loue hate thou must dead pitous hond mote smite thine head ala euer appius thee sey thus hath falsely iudged thee dey told case ye han heard needeth tell mercy dere father qd maid word armes laid necke wont teares brast eyen two said good father shall die grace remedie certes deare doughter mine qd yeue leaue father mine qd death complaine little space parde iepte yaue doughter grace complaine ere slough ala god wot nothing trespas ran father first see welcome great solemnitee word fell aswoune anone swouning gone riseth vp father said blessed god shall die maid yeue death ere haue shame doth child wil god name word praieth full oft swerd smite soft word aswoune doune fell father sorrowfull heart fell head smote top hent iudge yaue present sat doome consistorie iudge saw saith storie bad take hong also fast right anone people thrast saue knight routh pity knowen iudges iniquity people anon suspect thing manner client challenging assent appius wist well letcherous unto appius gone kesten prison right anone whereas slew himselfe claudius seruant vnto appius demed honged vpon tree virginius great pitee prayed exiled el certes beguiled remnaunt honged lesse consented cursednesse may men see sin hath merite beware man wot god wol smite degree ne manner wise worme conscience woll arise wicked life though priuie man wote god whether leaud man lered soone may affered therefore rede counsaile take forsake sinne sinne forsake pthe word host host gan sweare wood harrow qd nailes blood false theefe cursed iustice shamefull death heart may deuise come iustice aduocas algate silly maiden slaine ala ala deare abought beautee wherefore say men may see yefts fortune nature cause death many creature beauty death dare well saine ala pitously slaine hereof woll proceed men haue full oft harme prow truly truly mine owne maister dere ernefull tale nathelesse passe ouer force pray god saue thy gentle corce thy vrinals thy iordanes thine ypocras eke thy galianes euery boxe full letuarie god blesse hem lady saint marie mote thee thou art proper man ylike prelate saint runian saue cannot speake well terme well wot thou dost mine hert yerne haue almost ycaught cardiacle corpus domini haue triacle el draught moist cornie ale heare anon another merry tale heart lost pity maid thou belamy thou iohn pardoner said tell v merry tale iape right anon shall done qd saint runion first qd ale stake woll drinke bite cake right anone gentles gan crie nay let tell v ribaudrie tell v morall thing yt mow lere wit woll gladly graunt qd ywis ye cup ile think honest thing while drink pthe pardoner prologue lordings qd chirch preche paine mee haue hauteine speche ring round doth bell rote tell teme alway one euer radix omnium malorum est cupiditas first prono nce fro whence come bils shew liege lord seale patent shew first body warrent man bold priest ne clerke disturbe christ holy werke tell forth tale buls pope cardinales patriarkes bishop shew latine speake word sauer predication stere men deuotion shew forth long christall stone ycrammed full clout bone relickes wene echone haue laton shoder bone holy iewes shepe good men say take word kepe bone washen well cow calfe sheepe oxe swell worme hath eaten hem stong take water well wash tong hole anon furthermore pockes scab euery sore shall shepe hole well drinketh draught take keepe yt tell good man beast oweth woll euery day ere cocke croweth fasting drinke well draught thilke holy iew elder taught beast store shall multiplie sir also healeth jealousie though man fall jealous rage let make water potage never shall wife mistrist though sooth defaut wist taken priest two three mittaine eke ye may see hand woll put mittaine shall multiplying graine hath sowen wheat otes offer good pen grotes men woman thing warne wight church hath done sinne horrible dare shame shriuen woman yong old hath made husbond cokewold folke shull haue power ne grace offer relickes place findeth blame commeth offer god name assoyle authoritie bull graunted vnto gaude haue every yere hundred marke sithen pardonere stond like clerke pulpet leud people doune yset preach ye haue lered tell hundred yapes paine stretch forth necke east west vpon people becke doth dove sitting upon berne honds tongue gone yerue joy see businesse avarice cursednesse preaching maken hem free yeuen pen namely vnto mine entent winne nothing correction sinne recke neuer ben buried though soule gone black buried certes many predication commeth oft time evill entention pleasaunce folke flaterie auaunced hipocrisie vaineglory hate dare wayes debate woll sting hem tongue smert preaching shall astert ben defamed falsely hath trespassed bretherne though tell proper name men shall well know signes circumstaunces thus quite folke yt doth v displeasaunces thus put venum hew holinesse seemen holy trew shortly mine entent woll deuise preach nothing couetise therefore teme yet ever radix omnium malorum est cupiditas thus preach ayenst vice use avarice though self guilty sinne yet maken folke twinne auarice sore hem repent principal entent preach nothing couetise matere ought ynough suffise tell hem ensamples many one old story done long time agone leaud people aye louen tale old thing well report hold trowen ye while may prech win gold siluer tech woll liue pouert wilfully nay nay thought neuer truly woll preach beg sundry londs woll doe labour mine honds ne make basket liue thereby woll beg idelly woll none apostle counterfete woll haue money mault cheese whete yeuen poorest page poorest widdow village though child sterue famine nay woll drinke licour wine haue jolly wench every toun hearkeneth lordings conclusioun liking tell tale haue drunken draught corny ale god hope shall tell thing shall reason liking though selfe full vicious man morall tale yet tell wont preach win hold peace tale woll begin pthe pardoner tale company riotours conspire kill death killeth one another flanders whilom companie yong folke haunted follie hasard riot stewes tauernes whereas harp lute geternes dauncen plaien dice night day eaten also ouer might may done deuill sacrifice within devil temple cursed wise superfluitie abhominable othes great damnable grisly heare hem sweare blessed lord body teare hem thought ye iews rent ynough hem others sinne lough right anon comen tomblesteres fetis smale yong foiteres singer harpes baud waferers verely deuils officer kindle blow fire letcherie annexed vnto glotonie holy writ take witnesse letchery wine dronkennesse lo dronken loth vnkindly lay daughter two vnwittingly dronke nist wrought therefore sore repenten ought herodes woll story seche may ye learne ensample teche wine replete feast right owne table yaue hest sleen iohan baptist full guiltlesse seneke saith eke good word doubtlesse saith difference find betwixt man mind man dronkelew woodnesse fallen shrew perseuereth lenger doth dronkennesse glotenie full cursednesse cause first confusion originall damnation til christ bouyt v blood lo dere shortly sain bought first cursed villanie corrupt world throgh glotenie adam fornfather wife also fro paradice labour wo driven vice drede while adam fasted rede paradise hee eat fruit defended tree anon cast wo paine glotenie thee well ought v plaine oh wist man many malady followeth excesse glotenies would measurable diete sitting table ala short throat tender mouth maketh east west north south earth aire water men swinke getten glutton deinte meat drinke matter paul wel canst thou treat meat vnto wombe wombe eke vnto meat shall god destroien paule saith ala foule thing faith say word fouler dede men drinketh white rede throte maketh priue thilke cursed superfluite apostle saieth weeping full pitously walken many told haue say weeping pitous voice enemy christ croice end death womb god belly wombe stinking cod fulfilled dong corruptioun either end thee foule soun great cost labour find cooke lord stamp strein grind turne substance accident fulfill thy likerous talent hard bone knocken mary cast away may go gullet soft sote spicerie leaf barke rote shall sauce ymade delite maken hem newer appetite certes haunteth delices dead while liveth vice lecherous thing wine dronkennes full striving wretchednes oh dronken man disfigured thy face soure thy breath foul art thou enbrace thy dronken nose souneth soun tho thou saidest aie sampson sampsoun yet god wot sampson dronk never wine thou fallest sticked swine thy tongue lost thine honest cure drunkennesse sepulture man wit discretion drinke hath domination counsaile keepe drede kepe fro white fro rede namely fro white wine lepe sell fishstreet chepe wine spaine creepeth subtilly wine growing fast riseth fumositee man hath dronk draught three weneth home chepe spaine right toune lepe nought rochell ne burdeaux toun woll say sampsoun sampsoun herkeneth lordings word pray soveraigne act dare say victory old testament god yt omnipotent doen abstinence prayere looketh bible ye mow lere looketh attila great conquerour died sleepe shame dishonour bleeding aye nose drunkennesse captaine liue sobernesse auise right well commaunded unto lamuel samuell lamuel say redeth bible find expresly wine yeuing hem haue justice may well suffice spoke glotonie woll defend hasardrie hasard mother lesings deceit cursed forswearing blaspheme christ manslauyter wast also cattel time mo repreue contrary honour holden common hasardour ever higher estate holden desolate prince shall use hasardrie gouernaunce pollicie common opinion hold lesse reputation stillebon hold wise embassadour sent corinth full great honour fro calidone maken hem alliaunce came happed chaunce greatest lond playing hasard hem yfond soone might stale home ayen countre saied woll lese name nill take great defame allie none hasardours sendeth wiser embassadours trouth leuer die hasardours alie ye glorious honour shall alie hasardours ne treatie wise philosopher thus saied looke eke king demetrius king parthes ye booke saieth v sent paire dice gold scorne vsed hasardrie biforne held glory renoun value reputatioun lord might find manner play honest ynough driue day away wol speake othes false great word two bookes entreat great swearing thing abhominable false swearing yet reprouable high god forbad swearing witnesse mathew speciall swearing saieth holy ieremie thou shalt sweare sooth thine othes lie sweare dome eke rightwysnes idle swearing cursednesse behold see first table high god hestes ben honourable second hest take name idlenesse amis lo rather forbiddeth swearing homicide cursed thing say thus order stondeth knoweth yt hests vnderstondeth second hest god furthermore woll thee tell plat vengeaunce shall part fro hous othes outrageous god precious heart nailes bloud christ hailes seuen chaunce thine fiue three god armes thou falsly play dagger shall thine heart ygo fruit commeth thilke bone two swearing ire falsenesse homicide loue christ v dide leaueth othes great smale shall tell meruellous tale roitours three tell long erst prime rong bell set hem tauerne drinke sat heard bell clinke corse carried graue one hem gan call knaue goe bette qd aske redily corse passeth forth looke thou report name wele sir qd needeth neuer dele told ere ye came two hour parde old fellow suddainly slaine night drunke sat bench vpright came priuy theefe men clepen death countrey people aeth speare smote heart wo went way withouten word mo hath thousand slaine pestilence maister ere ye come presence thinketh necessarie beware aduersarie bethe redy meten euermore thus taught dame say saint mary saied tauernere child sayeth sooth hath yere hen ouer mile slaine great village man woman child page trowe habitation auised great wisdome ere man dishonour ye god armes qd riotour perill meet shall seeche stile eke street make auow god digne bone herkeneth fellowes three one let ech v hold vp hond ech v become others brother woll slea false traitour death shall slaine many slaeth god dignity ere night togider han three trouths plight liue die ech though owne brother vp stert dronken rage forth gone toward village tauerner hath spoken many gris othe ha swore christes blessed body rent death shall dead may hent han gone fully mile right would haue troden ouer stile old poore man hem met old man full meekely hem gret saied lordings god ye see proudest riotours three answerd ayen churle hard grace art thou forwrapped saue thy face liuest thou long great age old man gan looken visage saied thus cannot find man though walked iude neither city ne village would chaunge youth mine age therefore mote haue mine age still long time shall god ne death ala ill haue life thus walke like restlesse caitife ye ground mother gate knocke staffe erliche late say still leue mother let lo vanish flesh blood skin ala shall bone rest mother would chaunge chest chamber long time hath ye heren clout wrap yet woll doen grace full pale welked face sir ne courtesie speaken vnto old man villanie trespace word either dede holy writ may selfe well rede ayenst old man hore vpon hede ye arise therefore rede ne doeth old man harme ye would man age ye may long abide god whether ye go ride mote go thider go nay old churle god thou shalt saied hasardours anon thou partest lightly saint iohn thou spakest riyt thilke traitor death country friend slaeth trouth thou art espie tell el thou shalt die god holy sacrament soothly thou art assent slea v yong folke thou false thefe sir lefe find death tourne vp crooked way groue left fay vnder tree woll abide ne bost nill nothing hide se ye yonder oke right ye shall find god saue bought ayen mankind amend thus saied old man eueriche riotours ran til came ye tree found floreines gold fine oined round well nigh seuen bushel hem thought lenger death sought ech hem glad sight floreins faire bright doune sit precious hord yongest hem spake first word brother qd take keepe say wit great though bord play treasure hath fortune v yeuen mirth iollity life liuen lightly come woll spend heie god precious hart wend day yt faire grace might gold caried fro place home house el vnto well wote yt gold high felicite truly day may men would say wer theeues strong owne treasure doen v hong treasure must yearied night wisely slily might wherefore rede draw cut among v let u see cut woll fall hath shortest cut hart blith shall renne toune full swith bring v bread drinke full priuely two u shall keepe full subtilly treasure well woll tarie night woll treasure carie one assent v list best one hem brought grasse fest bad hem draw look wold fall fell yongest hem forth toward toune went anone also soone gone one hem spake vnto thou wost well thou art sworne brother thy profite woll tell thee right anone thou wost well fellow gone gold yt full great plentee shall departed among v three nathelesse shape departed among v two doen friendly turne thee answerd yt might woll well gold two doe might shall counsaile said first shrew shall tell thee word woll doen bring well graunt qd dout trouth woll thee bewrain qd thou wost well twain twain v shall stronger one looke set anone arise thogh thou wouldest play shall riuen side tway while yt thou struglest game thy dagger looke thou ye shall good departed owne dere friend betwixt thee may lust fulfill play vice right owne thus accorded ben shrew tway slea third ye heard say yongest yt went ye toune full often hart rolled doune beauty floreines faire bright lord qd might haue treasure selfe alone ni man liueth vnder trone god liue merry last fiend enemy put thought shuld poison bey might slaen felows twey fiend fond liuing leue sorrow bring vtterly entent slaen hem neuer repent forth goth lenger would tary toune vnto potecary praied would sell poyson might rat quell eke polkat hawe saied capon yslaw said would wreken yt might vermine destroied hem night poticarie answerd thou shalt haue thing wisly god soule saue world ni creature eateth drinketh confecture mountenaunce corne ne shall life anone forlete ye sterue shall lesse thou woldest gone apace mile poison hard violent tursed man hath hond hent poison boxe swithe ran next street unto man borrowed large bottle three two poison poured third kept cleane drinke night shope swinke carying gold place riotour sorry grace hath fild great bottle three fellowes ayen repaired hee needeth thereof sermon right cast death right han slain yt anone doen spake yt one let u sit drinke make v mery afterward wolne body bury happed hem per caas one took bottle ye poison dronke yaue fellow drinke also anon steruen two certes suppose auicenne wrote neuer chanon ne fenne wonder sorrow empoysoning wretch two ending thus ended homicide two eke false empoysoner also cursed sinne full cursednesse traitour homicide wickednesse glotenie luxurie hasardie thou blasphemour christ villanie othes great vsage pride ala mankind may betide thy creatour yt thee wrought precious blood thee bought thou art false vnkind ala good men god foryeue trespas ware fro sinne auarice mine holy pardon may warish ye offer noble starling el siluer spoones brooch ring boweth head vnder holy bull commeth vp ye wiues offreth wol name enter roll anone blisse heauen shull ye gone assoile mine high powere ye offren cleane clere ye borne lo sir thus preach iesu christ soules leach graunt pardon receiue best woll deceiue sir one word foryate tale haue relickes pardon male faire man man englond yeuen pope hond woll deuotion offren haue mine absolution commeth forth anon kneeleth adoun ye may haue part pardoun el taketh pardon ye wend new fresh euery tounes end ye offren alway new new noble pen good trew great honour euerich ye may haue sufficient pardonere assoile countrey ye ride auentures may betide perauenture may fall one two doune hors breke neck atwo look suertie fellowship yfall may assoile lasse soule shall fro thy body passe rede host shall first beginne enuelopt sinne commeth forth sir host offer first anone thou shalt kisse relikes euerichone ye grote vnbokell anon thy purse nay nay qd haue christ curse let qd shall theiche thou wouldest make kisse thine old brech sweare relike saint though thy foundement depaint crosse saint helain fond would thine coilons mine hond insteed relikes sanctuarie let cut hem woll help thee hem carie shull shrined hog tord pardoner answered word wroth would word say qd host woll lenger play thee ne none angrie man right anon worthy knight began saw people lough right ynough sir pardoner merry glad chere ye sir host dere pray ye kisse pardonere pardoner pray thee draw thee nere let u lough play anon kissed ride forth way pthe shipmans prologue friendes said host dere liketh iohn ye pardonere hath vnbokeled well male hath u told right thriftie tale touching men misgouernaunce pray god yeue full good chaunce ye han heard riotours three gentle mariner heartely pray thee tell u good tale right anon shall doen god saint iohn said mariner well euer right anon tale thus began pthe shipmans tale marchant denise cozened wife monke called dan john argument taken bochas novel marchant whilome dwelled saint denise rich men held wife excellent beaute compinable reuelous wise thing yt causeth dispence worth chere reuerence men hem doen feast daunces salutation countenaunces passeth doeth shaddow wall wo pay mote sely husbond algate mote pay mote v clothe eke array owne worship richely array dauncen jolily may perauenture el lust spece endure thinketh wast ylost mote another pay cost lend v gold perillous noble marchant held noble hous day great repaire largesse wife faire wonder herkeneth tale among guells great imale monke faire man bold trow thirtie winter old euer one drawing place yong monke faire face acquainted well good man sithens first knowledge began house familiar possible friend much good man eke monke began two yborne one village monke claimed cousinage againe saied nay glad thereof foule day heart great pleasaunce thus ben knit eterne alliaunce eke hem gan ensure brotherhed while life may dure free dan iohn namely dispence hous full diligence doe pleasaunce eke great costage foryate yeue least page house degree yaue lord sithen meinee yt came maner honest thing glad comming foule faine sunne vp riseth hereof suffiseth befell marchaunt day shope make ready array toward toune bruges fare buy portion ware hath sent paris anon messenger praied hath dan ihon come denis plain wife day twain bruges went wise noble monke deuise hath abbot list licence man high prudence eke officer ride seene graunges berne wide vnto saint denis commeth anon welcome lord dan iohn dere cousin full courtesie brought jubbe maluesie eke another full fine vernage volatily aye vsage thus let hem eat drinke play marchant monke day tway third day marchaunt vp riseth need sadly aviseth vp counting house goth reckon himselfe well may thilke yere stood dispended good encreased none bookes bagges many one laieth afore counter bord full rich treasure hord full fast counter dore shet eke nolde man let account meane time thus sate till passed prime dan iohn risen morrow also garden walked fro hath thing saied full courtes good wife come walking priuely garden walked soft salueth hath doen full oft maiden child came companie lust may gouerne gie yet vnder yerd maid dere cousin mine dan iohn said aileth rathe rise nece qd ought ynough suffise fiue houres sleepen night old palled wight old wedded men yt lie dare forme sitteth weary hare al forstraught hound great smale deere nece looke ye pale trowen certes good man hath laboured sith night began need resten hastely word lough full merely owne thought woxe fall red faire wife gan shake hed saied thus ye god wote qd nay cousin mine stonds god yave soule life ye realme fraunce wife lesse lust hath sory play may singen ala welaway borne wight qd dare tell stont wherefore think world wend el selfe soone make end full drede eke care monk began vpon wife stare saied ala nay nece god forbede ye sorrow drede fordoe selfe telleth greefe perauenture may mischeefe counsaile helpe therefore telleth annoy shall secre porthose make oth neuer life lefe ne loth ne shall counsaile bewray ayen qd say god porthose sweare though men would peeces teare ne shall neuer goe hell bewray word thing ye tell cousenage ne alliaunce verely loue affiaunce thus sworne hereupon kist ilke hem told hem list cousin qd space none namely place would tell legend life suffred haue sith wife mine husbond though cosin nay qd monke god martin ni cousin vnto leafe hongeth ye tree clepe saint denis fraunce haue cause acquaintaunce haue loued specially abouen woman sikerly sweare profession telleth greefe least come adoun hasteth goth way anon dere loue qd dan iohn full lefe counsaile hide mote may lenger abide husbond worst man euer sith world began sithen wife sit tellen wight priuite neither bed ne none place god shild tell grace wife ne say husbond honour vnderstond saue vnto thus much tell shall helpe god nought worth degree value flie yet greueth nigardie well ye wot woman naturally desiren thing sixe well woulden husbonds hardy wise rich thereto free buxome wife fresh bed ilke lord v bled honour selfe array sunday next comming mote need pay hundred frankes el lorne yet leuer vnborne done slaunder villanie mine husbond eke might espie nere lost therefore prey lene summe el mote dey dan iohn say lene hundred frank parde woll faile thanks ye list doe pray certain day woll pay wt pleasaunce seruice may done right ye list deuise god take vengeaunce foule euer genilion fraunce gentle monk answerd manere truly mine owne lady dere haue qd great touth swere plight trouth husbond flanders fare woll deliuer care woll bring hundred frankes caught ye flankes embraced hard kissed oft goth way qd still soft let u dine soone euer ye may kalender prime ye day goth beth true shall el god forbid good sir said forth goth iolly pie bad cooke yt hem hie men might dine yt anone vp husbond wife gone knocked counter dore boldely qui est la qd peter qd long woll ye fast long time woll ye recken cast sum bookes thing diuell haue part reckoning ye haue ynough qd god sond come doun day let bag stond ne ye ashamed dan iohn shall fasting long day gon let v go heare masse go dine wife qd man little canst thou diuine curious businesse haue u chapman god saue lord called saint iue scarsly among twenty twelue shall thriue continually lasting vnto age may well make chere good visage driue forth world may keepe state priuite till dead el play pilgrimage gone way therefore haue great necessite vpon queint world aduise euermore mote stand drede hap fortune chapmanhede flanders woll gone morrow day come ayene sone euer may dere wife thee beseke euery wight buxom meke keepe good curiouse honestly gouerne well house thou hast ynough euery maner wise thrifty huswife may suffice thee lacketh none array ne vitaile siluer thy purse thou maiest faile yt word counter dore shette goth lenger would lette hastily masse isaide spedily table ilaide dinner fast hem spedde richly chapman monke fedde dinner dan iohn soberly chapman tooke apert priuily said thus cousin stondeth well see bruges ye woll go god saint austen spede gide pray cousin wisely ride gouerne well also diete temperatly namely hete betwixt u two nedeth strange fare farewell cousin god shilde fro care thing day night lie power might ye woll command wise shall done right ye woll deuise thing ye go may wold faine pray lene hundred frankes weke twey certaine beast yt mote need bey store therewith place god helpe would shall faile surely day thousand frankes mile way let thing secret pray yet night beast mote bey fare wele mine owne cousin dere grant mercie cost chere noble marchant gentilly anon answerd said cousin dan ihon likerly small request gold lest onely gold chaffare list god shild ye spare one thing ye know well inough chapman money plough may haue creaunce haue name goodlesse shame pay ayen lieth ese might faine would plese hundreth frankes fet forth anon priuily tooke hem dan iohn wight world wist lone sauing marchant dan iohn alone drinke speak rome pley till dan iohn rideth abbey morow came forth rid marchant flanders ward prentes brought hem auant til came bruges wel merely goeth marchant well besily nedes buieth creaunseth neither playeth dice ne daunceth marchant shortly tell led life let dwell sonday next yt marchant gon saint denis comen dan iohn croune berde fresh new ishaue house na litle knaue ne wight el full faine yt lord dan iohn comen againe shortly point gon faire wife accordeth dan iohn c frankes night haue armes bolt upright accord parformed dede mirth night besie life lede til day yt dan iohn yede way manie farewell good day none hem ne wight toun dan iohn suspectioun forth rideth home abbey liste sey marchant ended faire saint denis gan repaire wife maketh feest chere telleth chaffare dere need must make cheuesaunce bonden reconysaunce pay twentie thousand shildes anon marchant paris gon borrow certaine friend certaine frankes lad comen toun cherite great affectioun vnto dan iohn first goth pley nought borrow money wete see welfare tellen chaffare friend mette infere dan iohn maketh feast mercy chere tolde ayen full specially bought full well graciously thonked god hole marchandise saue must manner wise maken cheuesaunce best ioy rest dan iohn answered certes right fane ye heale commen home againe rich blisse twenty thousand shildes shuld ye misse ye kindly day lent gold may thonke god saint iame natheles k unto dame wife home gold againe vpon bench wote wel certaine certaine token tell leave may longer dwell abbot woll toun anon company mote gon grete well dame mine neece swete farewell deare cousin till mete marchant full ware wise creaunced hath eke paide paris certaine lombardes redy honds sum gold gate hem bond home goth mery popingay well knew stood aray need must win viage thousand frankes costage wife full ready mete yate wont old usage algate night mirth sette rich clerely dette day marchant gan enbrace wife new kissed face goeth made wonder tough qd god ye ynough wantonly ayen plaide till last marchant thus said god qd little worthe wife although lothe wote ye god gesse ye haue made maner strangenesse betwixt cousin dan iohn ye warned gon hundred frankes paide redy token held evill apaide spake cheuesaunce seemed countenaunce natheles god heavenly king thought aske nothing pray thee wife ne tell alway er fro thee go dettour hath mine absence ypaide thee lest thy negligence might aske thing hath paide wife aferde ne affraide boldly said anon mary defie false monke dan iohn keepe token neuer dele tooke certaine gold wote wele euill dome monkes snoute god wote wend without doute yeue doen therwith mine honour prow cosinage eke belle chere hath full often time sith see stonte disioynte woll answere shortly pointe ye haue mo slacke dettours woll pay well redely fro day day faile wife score taile shall pay soone ever may truth mine aray waste bestowed every dele bestowed wele honour god sake say wrothe let u laugh play ye shall joly bodie wedde god nill pay bedde foryeue mine owne spouse dere turneth hitherward make better chere marchant saw ther remedy chide foly sith thing may amended wife said foryeue thee thy life large keep bet good yeue thee charge thus endeth tale god u send taling inough unto life ende phere followeth wordes hoste well said corpus domini qd hoste long mote thou saile ye coste thou gentle maister gentle marinere god giue ye monk thousand last quad yere ha fellowes beware iape monke put marchants hode ape wife eke saint austin draweth monkes inne passe let u seeke aboute shall tell first route another tale word said curteously maid lady prioresse leaue wist shuld greue wolden deme ye tellen shold tale next ye wold wol ye vouchsafe lady dere gladly qd said manere pthe prioress prologue domine dominus noster quam admirable est nomen tuum universa terra lord lord thy name merueilous wide world isprad qd onely thy laud precious parformed men dignite mouth child thy bounte parfourmed breest sucking sometime shewen thine heriyng wherefore laude best may thee white lilly floure thee bare maide alway tell storie wol labour nought may encrese honour selfe honour rote bountie next sonne soules bote mother maiden maiden mother fre bushe vnbrent brenn moyses sight rauishedest downe fro deite thin humblenes ye gost thee alight whose vertue thine hert pight conceiued father sapience helpe tell thy reuerence lady thy bountie thy magnificence thy vertue thy great humilite may tongue expresse science sometime lady er men pray thee thou goest thy benignite gettest v ye light thy prayere giden v vnto thy sonne dere conning weake blisfull queen declare thy high worthinesse ne may weight sustene childe twelue moneth old lesse vnnethes word expresse right fare therfore pray gideth song shall say pthe prioress tale miracle christian child murthered jewes asie great citie amonges christen folke certain iewrie sustened lorde countrie foule vsury lucre villany hatefull christ company strete men might ride wend free open euery end little schole christen folke stood farther end ther child hepe comen christen blood learned schole yere yere manere doctrine men vsen say singen rede smale child done childhede amonges child widow son litle clergion vii yeres age day day schole eke also sey image christes mother vsage taught kneele adown say aue maria goth way thus hath widow little child itauyt blessed lady christes mother dere worship aye foryate naught sely childe would day sone lere aye remember matere saint nicholas stondeth euer presence yong christ reuerence litle childe litle booke lerning sate schole primere alma redemptoris mater herd sing child lered antiph nere durst drewe aye nere nere harkened wordes note till first verse couth al rote nouyt wist latin say yong tender age day felow han pray expound song language tellen song vsage praid constre declare full often time vpon knee bare felow elder answerd thus song haue herd say made blessed lady fre f lewe eke prey help succour dey expoune mater lerne song small grammer song imade reuerence christes mother said innocent ce e woll done diligence conne er christenme se went though primer shall shent beten thrise houre woll conne ladie honoure felow taught homeward priuely fro day day till couth rote sung well boldely fro word according note twise day passed throte homeward went christes mother set entent haue said throughout iewrie little child came fro ful merely would sing crie alina redemptoris mater euer mo sweetnes hath hert persed christes mother pray cannot stint singing way first foe serpent sathanas hath iewes hert waspes nest vp swale said chrake people ala thing honest boy shall walke le te dispite sing sentence lawes reuerence thenceforth iewes han conspired innocent world chase homicide han hired aley priuie place child gan foreby pa e cursed iew hent held fast cut throte pit cast say wardrope threw iewes purged intraile cursed folke heraudes new may euil entent auaile murder woll certes woll faile namely ther ye honor god shall spred blood crieth cursed deed martyr founded virginitie maist thou sing folowing euer white lambe celestiall qd great euangelist saint iohn pathmos wrote saieth yt gon lambe sing song new neuer fleshly woman ne knew poore widow awaiteth al night little childe came nought soone day light face pale drede busy thought hath schole el sought till finally gan farre aspie last sene iewrie mother pitie breast enclosed goth halfe minde euery place hath supposed likelihood child finde euer christes mother good kinde cried last thus wrought among cursed iewes sought freneth praieth pitously euery iew dwelleth thilke place tellen child went say nay iesu grace yaue thought within little space place sonne cryde cast pit beside great god performest thy laude mo th innocencie loe thy might iemme chastitie emerande eke martirdome rubie bright throte icorne lay vpright alma redemptoris gan sing loude place gan ring christen folk yt street went comen wonder thing hasteley prouost sent came anon without tarying herieth christ heauen king eke mother honour mankind iews let binde child pitous lamentation vp taken singing song alway honour great procession carien next abbey mother sowning bere lay vnneath might people new rachell bringen fro bere turment shamefull deth like one prouost doth iews sterue murder wiste anone nolde cursednesse obserue euill shall haue euil wol deserue therefore wild horse hem draw afterward hong hem law vpon bere aye lieth innocent beforn cheef aulter while masse last abbot couen hem spedde burie al fast holy water cast yet spake yt child sprint holy water sang alma redemptoris mater abbot yt holy man monkes el ought yong childe couer began said dere child hailse thee vertue holy trinitie tell thy cause sing sithens thy throte cut seeming throte cut vnto necke bone said child way kind haue deyd ye long time agone iesus christ ye bookes find woll glory last minde worship mother dere yet may sing alma loude clere wel mercie christ mother swete loued alway conning life forlete came bad sing antem verily dying ye han herde song thought laid graine vpon tong wherefore sing sing mote certaine honour blisfull maiden free till fro tongue taken graine thus said little child woll fetch thee yt graine fro thy tong itake agaste woll thee forsake holy monke abbot mene tong caught toke away yt graine yaue vp ghost full softly abbot wonder seyne salt teres trikled reyne groffe fell flat ground still lay ibound couent lay eke vpon pauement weeping herying christes mother dere risen forth ben went tooke away martir fro bere tonthe marble stone clere enclosen litle body swete god leue v mete yong hew lincolne slaine also cursed iewes notable little ago pray v sinfull folke vnstable mercie god merciable u great mercy multiply reuerence mother mary phere followeth wordes hoste chaucer said miracle euery man sober wonder see till hoste yapen began erste looked vpon said thus man art thou qd thou lookest thou wouldest finde hare euer vpon ground see thee stare approch neere looke vp merely ware sir let man haue place waste shapen well popet armes enbrace woman small faire face semeth eluish countenance vnto wight doth daliance say somewhat sithens folke han said tell v tale mirth anon hoste qd ne euil apaide tale certes none rime lerned yore agone ye good qd shullen deinte thing thinketh thy chere phere followeth rime sir thopas northern tale outlandish knight purposely uttered chaucer differing rime stile tale though author onely reporter rest listeneth lordinges good entent woll tell verament mirth solas knight faire gent battaile turnament name sir thopas iborne ferre countre flaunders beyonde see popering place father man full fre lord countre god grace sir thopas doughty swaine white face paine maine lippes reed rose rudde like scarlet graine tell good certaine seemely nose haire berde like safroun girdle raught adowne shoone cordewane bruges hosen broun robe chekelatoun cost many iane couth hunt wilde dere ride hauking riuere grey goshauke honde thereto good archere wrastling none pere ram stonde full many maide bright boure mourne paramoure whan hem bet sleepe chaste lechoure sweet bramble floure beareth red hipe befell vpon day forsoth tell may sir thopas would ride wroth vpon stede gray honde launce gay long sword side pricketh faire forest therein many wild beest ye bucke hare pricked north easte tellen almeste betide sory care springen herbes great small licores setual many clowe gelofer nutmiges put ale whether new stale lie cofer bird singen nay sperhauke popingaie ioy throstell eke made laie wood doue vpon spraie sung full loude clere sir thopas fill loue longing heard throstill sing pricketh wood faire stede pricking sweete men might wring side blood sir thopas eke wearie pricking soft graas fiers corage downe laied place maken stede solace gaue good forage oh saint mary benedicite aileth loue blinde sore dreamed night parde elfe queene shall lemman sleep vnder gore elfe queene woll loue wi world woman make towne woman forsake elfe quene take dale eke doune saddle e clombe anone pricked ouer stile stone elfe queene spie till long ridden gone found priuie wone countrey fairie wherein sought north south oft spied mouth many forrest wilde countre na none farre rid gone neither wife ne childe till came great giaunt name called sir oliphaunt perillous man deede swore child termagaunt pricke haunt anon slea thy steede queene fairie harpe pipe simphonie within place boure childe saied al mote thee morow woll meten thee whan haue mine armoure yet hope par faie thou shalt launce gaie abien thy mawe thy hawberke shall perce may fully prime day thou shalt slawe sir thopas droue abacke full fast gyaunt stone cast fell staffe sling faire escaped sir thopace god grace faire bearing yet listneth lordings tale merier nightingale woll ye roune sir thopas side smale pricking ouer doune dale comen ayen toune merry men commanded maken game gle needes must fight giant head thre paramour iolite one shone full bright doe come said liggen hood bright helme wanger fed destrer hearbes fine good himselfe dronke water well knight sir persiuell worthy wede pthe word hoste god dignite q hoste thou makest wearie thy leudenes also willy god soule blesse mine eares aken thy draftie speach riche deuill beteach may wel clepe rime dogrel qd qd wolt thou let tale man sin best time god qd plainly worde thy draftie timing worth torde thou doest nought el spendest time sir one word thou shalt lenger rime let see whether thou canst tell ought gest tell prose somewhat lest ther may mirth doctrine gladly qd god swete pine woll tell little thing prose ought like suppose else ye certes dangerous morall tale vertuous tolde sometime sundry wise sundry folke shall devise thus ye wote every evangelist telleth u paine iesu christ ne saith thing fellow doth nathelesse sentence soth accorden sentence telling difference hem saien lesse whan pitous passion expresse meane marke matthew luke iohn doubtlesse sentence one therefore lordings beseech thinke vary speech thus although tell somewhat proverbes ye han heard comprehended little treatise enforcen effect matere though word say ye han heard yet pray blameth sentence shull ye finde mochell difference fro sentence treatise lite little tale write therefore hearkeneth shall say let tell tale pray pchaucers tale melibeus prudence discreet wife melibeus persuadeth husband patience receive enemy mercy grace tale full morality wherein high low may learn govern affection ayong man called melibeus mighty rich begate upon wife called prudence doughter called sophie vpon day befell disport went field play wife eke doughter left within house doores fast ishet foure old foe han aspied setten ladder walles house windowes beene entred bet wife wounded doughter five mortall woundes five sundry place say foot honds eares nose mouth leften dede wenten way melibeus returned house see mischiefe hee like mad man renting clothes gan weep crie prudence wife farre foorth shee durst besought weping stint thy gan weep cry ever lenger noble wife prudence remembred upon sentence ovid booke cleped remedy loue whereas saith hee foole distourbeth mother weepe death childe till wept fill certain time shall man doen diligence amiable wordes recomfort pray weeping stint reason noble wife prudence suffered husbond weepe cry certaine space saw time shee saied wise ala lord qd make ye selfe like foole forsoth apperteineth unto wise man maken sorowe doughter grace god shall warish escape right dead yee ne ought death self destroy senek saith wise man shall take great discomfort death child certes suffer patience wel abideth ye death proper person melibeus answered anon said man qd weping stint hath great cause weep iesus himselfe lorde wept death lazarus friend prudence answered certes well wote temperat weeping nothing defended sorowfull among folke sorow rather graunted weepe apostle paule unto romanes writteth men rejoyce maketh joye weepe folke weepen though temperate weeping granted certes outragious weeping defended measure weeping considered lore teacheth u senek yt thy friend dead qd let thine iyen moist teers ne much drie although teeres comen thine eyen let hem fall thou hast forgon thy friend doe diligence get another friend wisedom weepe thy friend thou hast lorne therein bote therefore ye govern sapience put away sorow heart remembreth iesus sirake saieth man yt joyous glad hart conserueth florishing age sothly sorowfull heart maketh bone drie hee saith eke thus sorow heart slayeth full many man salomon sayeth right mouth sheepes fleise annoieth clothes small wormes tree right anoieth sorow hart man wherefore u ought well death child losse temporal good patience remember upon patient iob hee lost child temporall substaunce body endured receiued full many grieuous tribulation yet saied hee thus lord sent lord hath bereft right lord would right done iblessed name lord foresaid thing melibeus unto wife prudence answered thy word qd ben true thereto profitable truely mine heart troubled sorrow grievously let call qd prudence true friend al thy linage wise telleth hem case hearkeneth say counsailing gouerne sentence salomon saith werke thy thing counsaile thou shalt never rue counsaile wife prudence melibeus let cause great congregation people surgiens phisitions old folke yong old enemy reconciled semblance loue grace therwithal came neighbour reverence dread loue happe ofte comen also ful many subtil flatterer wise advocate learned lawe folkes togeders assembled melibeus sorrowfull wise shewed hem case manner speech seemed hart bare cruell ire ready doen vengeaunce upon foe suddainly desired warre begin natheles yet asked counsaile upon matter surgien licence assent wise rose unto melibeus saied ye shall heare sir qd u surgiens appertaineth doe every wight best beene withholden patient wee dooen damage wherefore happeth many time ofte two men everch wounded one surgien healeth hem wherfore vnto arte pertinent norish warre ne party support certes ye warishing doughter perilously wounded shall doe tentife businesse fro day night grace god shall whole sound soone possible almost right wise phisitions answered saue yt saiden word right malady beene contrary cured right shall man warishe warre peace neigbours full enuie fained friend yt seemed reconciled flatterer maden semblaunce weeping enpaired agrutched much matter praysing greatly melibe might power rich friend dispising power aduersaries said vtterly hee anon wreken foe begin warre vp rose aduocate wise leaue counsaile wise saied neede wee beene assembled place full heauie thing great matter ye wrong wickednesse yt hath bee doen eke reason great damage time comming possible fallen eke reason ye great rich power party reason full great peril erren matter wherefore melibeus sentence counsaile abouen thing right anon thou doe thy diligence keeping thy proper person wise yt thou ne want non espie ne watch thy body saue yt counsaile yt thine house thou set sufficient garrison may well thy body thy house defend certes mouen warre doen suddainly vengeaunce may deeme little time profitable wherefore aske leiser space haue deliberation cause deme common prouerbe saith thus yt sone deemeth sone shall repent eke men saine thilke iudge wise yt sone vnderstondeth matter iudgeth leiser tarriyng noifull algate reproued yeuing iudgement ne vengeance taking sufficient reasonable yt shewed lord iesu christ ensample woman taken auoutrie brought presens knowen wt shuld doen person wist wel wt would answere yet ne would answere suddainly would haue deliberation ground wrote twise cause asken deliberation shall grace god counsaile thing shall profitable vp stert yong folke one part companie haue scorned old wise man begun make noise said right while iron hot men smite right men wreken wrong fresh new loud voyce cried warre warre vp rose one old wise hand made countenance holden hem still yeuen audience lordings qd full many man crieth warre warre wote full lite warre amounteth warre beginning hath great entring large every wight may enter liketh lightly find warre certes end thereof shall fall lightly know warre begun ful many child vnborne mother shal sterue yong thilke warre el liue sorrow dien wretchednesse therefore warre bee begon men must haue great counsaile good deliberation whan olde man wende enforten tale reason wel nie one begon rise breaken tale bidden full oft wordes abredge certes hee preacheth hem list heare wordes sermon hem annoieth iesus sirake sayeth yt weeping musick noious thing much say much auaileth speake beforne folk speech anoieth singen hem weepe wise man saw wanted audience shamefast set adown ayen salomon saith thou mayest audience enforce thee speake see well qd wise man common proverbe good counsail wanteth need yet melibeus counsaile many folke yt privily eare counsailed certain thing counsailed contrary general audience melibeus heard greatest part counsaile accorded make war anon consented counsailing fully affirmed sentence dame prudence saw husbonde shope awreke enemy begin warre shee full humble wise shee saw time sayed word lorde qd beseech heartily dare ne halfe fast guerdon yeue audience peter alphons saieth whoso doeth thee good harme haste thee quite wise thy friend woll abide thine enemie shall ye lenger liue dread prouerbe saieth hasteth well wisely abide wicked hast profite melibe answered wife prudence purpose qd werke thy counsaile many cause reason certes euery wight would hold mee foole say thy counsailing would change thing ordeined affirmed many wise secondly say woman beene wicked none good hem thousand men saith salomon found one good man certes al woman found neuer none also certes gouerned mee thy counsaile seeme yeue thee ouer mee ye maistrie god forbid iesus sirake saieth wife haue maistrie shee contrarious husbond salomon saieth neuer thy life thy wife ne thy childe ne thy friend ne yeue power ouer thy selfe better thy child aske thee thing hem needeth thy selfe hand thy child also woll werche thy counsail certes counsail must somtime secrete till time must bee knowen ne may bee counsailed thee dame prudence full debonairly great patience heard husbonde liked say asked licence speake saied wise lord qd first reason may lightly answerd say follie chaunge counsaile thing changed el thing seemeth otherwise seemed afore moreouer say though yee haue sworne behight performe emprise cause ye doe men say therefore ye lyer forsworn booke saieth wise man maketh lesing hee turneth corage better albeit emprise bee established ordeined great multitude folke yet dare accomplish thilke ordinance liketh trouth thing profit rather founden folke wise full reason great multitude folke every man crieth clattereth liketh soothly multitude honest ye second reason whereas ye say woman ben wicked save grace certes ye despise woman wise despiseth saith booke al displeaseth senecke saith woll haue sapience shall man dispraise shall gladly teach science without presumption pride thing nought ne hee shall beene ashamed learne hem enquire lesse folke himselfe yt ther hath ben many good woman may lightly prooued certes sir lord iesu christ nold neuer han discended borne woman woman wicked yt great bounte woman lord iesu christ risen death life appeared rather woman apostle tho salomon sayed found neuer woman good followeth therefore woman wicked though hee ne found good woman certes many another man hath founde many woman full good true el perauenture ye entent salomon soueraign bounte found woman say yt wight hath parfite bounte saue god alone himselfe recordeth euangelie ni creature good yt ne wanteth somwhat ye perfection god maker third reason ye say yt ye gouerne counsaile seeme ye yeue maistrie lordship person sir saue grace man bee counsailed onely hem han lordship maistrie person men nolde bee counsailed oft sothly thilke man asketh counsaile purpose yet hath free whither hee woll doe counsaile non fourth reason yee saine ianglerie woman hide thing wot saieth yt woman cannot hide wote sir wordes vnderstonde woman iangelers wicked woman men saine three thing driuen man house say smoke dropping raine wicked wiues woman salomon saieth man better dwell deserte woman riottous sir leaue ye haue full oft assaied great silence great patience eke well hide heale thing men oughten secretly hiden sothly fift reason whereas say yt wicked counsaile woman vanquish men god wote thilke reason stant stede vnderstondeth ye asken counsaile doe wickednes ye woll werken wickednes wife restraineth thilke wicked purpose ouercome reason good counsail certes wife ought rather bee praised blamed thus vnderstonde phylosopher yt saieth wicked counsaile woman vanquish husbondes ye blame al woman reason shall shewe many ensamples many woman haue full good yet counsaile wholesome profitable eke men han saied ye counsaile woman either deere little worth albeit yt full many woman bee bad counsaile vile nought worth yet han men found full many good woman full discrete wise counsailing lo iacob counsaile mother rebecke wan benison father lordship brother iudith thorow good counsaile deliuered citie bethule dwelt honde holofern besieged wold haue destroyed abigaile deliuered naball husbond fro dauid king yt would haue slaine appeased ire king wit good counsaile hester counsaile enhaunced greatly ye people god reigne assuerus king bountie good counsailing many good woman may men reade tell furthermore whan lord hath created adam former father hee saied wise good man alone make wee helper himselfe semblable may yee see woman good counsaile good profitable lorde god heauen ne would neither han wrought hem ne called hem helper man rather confusion man sayed clerke one two verse better gold iasper better iasper wisdom better wisdome woman better good woman good man better good man nothing sir many reason may yee seene many woman good eke counsaile good profitable therefore sir yee woll trust counsaile shall restore doughter hole sound eke woll doe much yt ye shall haue honour case melibe heard word wife prudence saied thus see well ye word salomon sooth saith word yt bee spoken discretly ordinaunce honicombes yeuen sweetnesse soule holsomnesse ye body wife thy sweet word eke haue proued assaied thy great sapience thy great trouth woll gouerne thy counsaile thing sir qd dame prudence sithens ye vouchsafe gouerned counsaile woll enforme yee shall govern self chusing counsailours ye shall first werke mekely beseeching high god yt would counsailour shapeth entent hee yeue counsaile comforte taught thobie sonne time thou shalt blesse god praie dresse thy way loke eke thy counsailes evermore saint iames saieth man neede sapience aske god afterwarde shullen ye take counsaile selfe examine well owne thought thing thinken beene best profit shall yee drive fro heart thing bee contrarious good counsaile say ire covetise hastinesse first yt asketh counsaile himselfe certes must withouten ire wrath himselfe many cause first hath great ire wrath himselfe weneth alway may doe thing may secondly irous wrothfull may well deeme hee may well deeme may well counsell third hee irous wroth saieth seneke may speake blamefull thing thilke vicious wordes hee stirreth folke anger ire eke sir yee must drive covetise heart ye apostle saith covetise roote harmes trusteth right well covetous man ne deem ne thinke fulfill end covetise certes ne may never accomplished evermore haboundance hath riches hee desireth sir ye must also drive heart hastinesse certes ye may deme best suddain thought falleth heart ye must advise full oft yee heard common proverb yt sone deemeth sone repenteth sir ye ne alway like disposition certes thing seemeth somtime good doe another time seemeth contrarie ye han taken counsaile selfe han deemed good deliberation thing seemeth best rede yee keepe secret bewray yee counsaile person yee wene sikerly bewraying condition shall bee profitable iesus sirake saith neither thy foe ne thy friend discover thy secret ne thy folly woll yeue audience looking supportation presence scorn absence another clerke sayth scarsly shall finde person may keepe counsaile secretly booke saieth thou keepest counsaile thine heart thou keepest thy prison thou bewrayest thy counsaile wight hee holdeth thee snare therefore better hide counsaile heart pray yee bewrayed counsaile woll keepe close still seneca saieth thou maiest thine owne counsaile hide howe darest thou pray wight thy counsaile secret keepe nathelesse thou wene sikerly thy bewraying thy counsaile person woll make thy condition stonde ye better plight shalt thou tell thy counsaile wise first thou shalt make semblant whether thee lever peace warre ne shewe thy ne thine entent trust well commonly counsailours beene flatrerers namely counsailours great lordes enforce hem alway rather speak pleasant word enclining lordes lust word ben trew profitable therfore men say ye rich man hath seld good counsaile hee himselfe thou shalt consider thy friendes thine enemy touching thy friendes thou shalt consider hem faithfull wise eldest approved counsailing hem shalt thou aske thy counsaile case requireth say first yee shall call counsaile friend true saloman saith right ye heart man deliteth savour sote right counsaile true friend yeueth swetenesse soule hee saieth also may nothing likened ye true friend certes gold ne silver bee much worth good true friend also saith true friend strong defence findeth hath great treasure shall ye also consider true friend discreet wise booke saith aske alway thy counsaile bin wise reason shall ye call counsaile friend yt beene age seeme beene expert many thinges approoved counsailing booke saieth olde men sapience long time prudence tullius saieth great thing beene aye accomplished strength ne delivernesse body counsaile aucthoritie person science three thing ne beene feeble age certes enforce encrease day day shall ye keep generall rule first shall yee call counsaile fewe friend yt especial salomon saieth many friend thou among thousand chuse thee one bee thy counsailour bee thou first ne tell thy counsaile fewe thou mayest afterwarde tell mo folke bee neede looke alway thy counsaylours condition sayd yt say true wise old experience werke alway every need one counsailer alone sometimes behooueth bee counsailed many salomon sayth saluation thing many counsaylers haue told folke yee shall counsailed woll tell cousaile yee ought eschew first yee shall eschew counsailing fooles salomon sayth take counsaile foole hee woll counsaile owne lust affection booke sayth propertie foole troweth lightly harme euery man lightly troweth bountie himselfe thou shalt eschew counsailing flaterers enforcen hem rather praise person flatterie tell soothfastnesse thing wherefore tullius sayeth among pestilence friendship greatest flatterie therefore need yt thou eschew dread flatterer people booke saith thou shalt rather flee fro sweete wordes flattering praising fro eagre word thy friend saith sooth salomon saith word flatterer snare catch innocence sayth also yt speaketh friend wordes flatterie pleasaunce setteth net beforne foot catch therefore tullius sayth encline thine eares flatterer ne take counsaile flatterer caton sayeth auise thee well eschew wordes sweetnesse pleasaunce eke thou shalt eschew counsailing thine old enemy reconciled booke sayth wight retourneth safely grace old enemie isope sayth ne trust hem thou hast sometime war enmity ne tell hem thy counsaile seneck telleth ye cause may sayth great fire hath long time endured dwelleth vapour heat therefore saith salomon thine old foe trust thou neuer likerly though thine enemie reconciled make signe humilitie loute thee head trust neuer certes maketh thilke faigned humility profite humility loue thy person deemeth haue victory ouer thy person fained countenaunce victorie might haue strife warre petrus alphons sayeth make fellowship thine old enemy thou hem bounty wollen pervert wickedness eke thou must eschew counsailing hem yt thy servaunts bearen thee great reverence peraventure sayne dread love therfore saith philosopher wise wight perfitly true dredeth tullius sayth might great emperour long may endure haue loue people dread ye shall eschew also counsailing folke dronklewe ne counsaile hide salomon sayth ni priuity reigneth drunkennesse ye shall haue also suspect ye counsailing folke counsaile one thing priuily counsaile contrarie openly cassidorie sayeth manner sleight hinder enemy sheweth done thing openly werketh priuily ye contrary thou shalt haue also suspect counsailing wicked folke alway full fraud dauid sayth blisfull man yt hath followed counsailing shrew thou shalt also eschew counsailing yong folke counsailing ripe salomon saith sir sithens haue shewed folke ye shall counsailed follow woll teach ye shall examine counsaile ye doctrine tullius examining counsailers ye shal consider many thing first thou shalt consider thilke thing thou purposest vpon thing thou wolt haue counsaile trueth said conserued say tell truly thy tale yt sayeth false may well counsailed case lieth thou shalt consider thing accorden yt thou purposest doe thy counsailours reason accord thereto eke thy might may attaine therto part better part counsailours accorden thereto shalt thou consider thing shall follow counsailing hate peace warre grace profite damage many thing thing shalt thou chuse best weiue thing shalt thou consider root engendred matter thy counsaile fruit may conceive engender thou shalt eke consider cause whence sprong thou hast examined thy counsaile haue said partie better profitable hast approoued many wise folke old thou shalt consider thou maiest performe make good end certes reason woll man shall begin thing might performe ought ne wight take vpon heauie charge yt might bere ye proverbe sayth much embraceth distraineth little caton saith assay thing thou hast power done least charge oppresse thee sore thee behooueth weiue thing yt thou hast begunne yt thou dout whether thou maiest performe thing none chuse rather suffer begin peter alphons saieth thou hast might thing thou must repent better holde thy tongue still speake maiest thou vnderstond stronger reason thou hast power perfourme werke thou shalt repent thee better thou suffer begin well saine defenden euery wight assay thing doubt whether may performe none ye haue examined counsaile haue said know well yee may performe emprise conferme sadly till bee end reason time shewe wherfore ye may chaunge counsaile withouten reproofe soothly man may change purpose counsaile cause ceaseth newe case betideth ye law saith vpon thing newly betideth behooueth newe counsaile seneke saieth thy counsaile come eares thine enemy chaunge thy counsaile thou maiest also chaunge thy counsaile thou find error cause harme dammage may betide also thy counsaile dishonest el come dishonest cause chaunge thy counsaile ye law saith behest dishonest ne value eke bee vnpossible may gladly perfourmed kept take general rule euery counsaile enformed strongly yt may chaunged condition may betide say ilke counsail wicked melibeus heard doctrine wife dame prudence aunswerd wise dame qd yet vnto time ye han well taught gouernaile shall gouern ye chusing withholding counsaile would faine ye would condiscend especial yt ye seemeth counsailours wee haue chose present need lord qd beseech humblesse yee woll wilfully replie ayenst reason ne distemper hert though speake thing displease god wote mine entent speake best honour profit eke soothly hope benignity woll take patience trusteth well yt counsaile case neshould speak properly called counsailing motion mouing folly counsaile ye haue erred many sundry wise first yee haue erred assembling counsailours first yee haue cleped fewe folke counsaile yee might haue shewed mo bee neede ye haue cleped counsail great multitude people full chargeous full noyous heare also ye haue erred yee haue onely cleped counsaile trew friend olde wise ye haue cleped straunge folke yong folk false flatterer enemy reconciled folk yt done reuerence withouten loue eke yee haue erred yee haue brought counsaile ire couetise hastinesse ye three thing contrary euery good counsaile honest profitable three thing yee haue destroyed neither self ne counsailours ye ought ye haue erred also yee haue shewed counsailours talent affection make warre anon vengeance haue espied word thing ye beene enclined therefore han rather counsailed talent profite ye han erred eke seemeth sufficeth haue counsailed counsailours onely little auisement whereas high great need necessarie mo counsailours deliberation performe emprise ye han erred also ye haue examined counsaile ye foresaid matter ne due manner case requireth ye haue erred also ye made diuision betweene true friend fained counsailours ne ye haue knowne trewe counsailours friend old wise ye haue cast word hochpot enclined heart part greater number fooles wise men therefore ye counsaylings beene congregation multitude folke men take regard number sapience person ye seene well yt counsaylings fooles han maistrie melibeus answerd said ayen graunt well haue erred thou hast told beforne yt ni blame chaungeth counsaile certaine case certaine cause redie chaunge counsailours right thou wouldest deuise prouerbe sayth done sinne mannish certes persevere long sinne werke diuell sentence answereth anone dame prudence said examineth qd well counsaile let v see hem hath spoke reasonably taught best counsaile much examination necessarie let v begin surgiens physician first spake matter say physician surgiens haue saied counsayle discreetly hem ought speech said full wisely office hem appertaineth done euery wight honour profite wight annoy craft done great diligence vnto cure hem haue gouernaunce sir right answerd wisely discreetly right read yt beene highly souerainly guerdoned noble speech eke shull done ententife businesse ye curation doughter beit friend therfore shullen ye suffer serue nought ye ought therafter guerdon hem pay hem largesse touching proposition physician entreteden case saine malady contrarie warished another contrary would faine know ye vnderstond thilke text sentence certes qd melibeus vnderstond wise right han doe contrary done hem another right han venged hem vpon done wrong right woll venge vpon hem done hem wrong haue cured one contrary another lo lo qd dame prudence lightly euery man enclined desire owne pleasaunce certes qd ye wordes physician ne vnderstond yt wise certes wickednesse contrary wickednesse ne vengeaunce contrarie vengeaunce ne wrong wrong euery hem encreaseth engendreth certes word physician vnderstond wise good wickednesse ben two contrary peace warre vengeaunce suffraunce discord accord many thing certes wickednesse shall warished goodnesse discord accord warre peace forth thing therto accordeth saint paule apostle many place sayth ne yeeld harme harme ne wicked speech wicked speech doe well hem done thee harme blesse hem saith thee harme many place admonisheth peace accord woll speke ye counsaile iyeue vnto men lawe wise folke old folke sayden one accord ye heard beforne ouer thing ye shall done businesse diligence keepe person warnstore house said also case ye ought werchen full wisely great deliberation sir first point toucheth keeping person ye shall vnderstond hath warre shall euer deuoutly meekly praien beforne thing iesu christ mercie woll haue protection soueraigne helper need certes world ni wight may counsailed ikept sufficiently without keeping lord iesu christ sentence accordeth prophet dauid yt sayth god ne kept citty idle waketh hee keepeth sir hee commit keeping person true friend approued iknow ye aske helpe person keep caton saith thou haue need helpe aske thy friend ni none good hhysician thy true friend shall yee keep fro straunge folke fro liers alway suspect companie peter alphons saieth ne take company way straunge man bee thou hast known lenger time fall thy companie peradventure withouten thine assent good enquire subtelly thou canst conversation life beforne faine thy way saying thou wouldest go thider thou wolt goe beare speare hold thee right side beare swerd hold thee left side shall ye keepe wisely manner people saied hem counsaile eschew shall yee keepe manner presumption bodily strength ye despise ne account might adversary lite ye let keeping person presumption every wise man dredeth enemie salomon sayth foole yt hath drede certes thorow hardnesse heart ye hardinesse himselfe hath great presumption shall euill betide shall ye euermore encounter waite embushments espiaile seneke sayeth wise man yt dredeth harmes escheweth harmes ne falleth peril perill escheweth thou seeme yt thou secret place yet shalt thou alway done diligence keeping thy person say ne negligent keepe thine owne person onely thy greatest enemy also thy least enemy seneke sayth man yt well aduised dreadeth least enemie ouid sayth ye little wesell woll slee ye great bull wild hart prouerbe sayth little thorn woll greeue king full sore little hound woll hold ye wild bore nathalesse say thou shalt coward thou doubt dred book sayth somemen haue great lust deceiue yet dread bee deceiued keepe thee fro ye companie scorner booke sayth scorner ne make company flie word venome second point whereas wise counsaylours counsayled warnestore house great dilligence would faine know yee vnderstond thilke wordes sentence melibeus answered said certes vnderstond wise shall warnestore mine house toures haue castle maner edifice armure archery betweene thing may person house keepe defend mine enemy shullen dread mine house approch sentence answered anon prudence warnishing qd high toures high edifice great costages great travaile yt ben accomplished yet bin worth straw defended true friend ben old wise understondeth well greatest strongest garnison rich men may well keepen person good beloved subject neighbour thus sayth tullius manner garrison yt man may vanquish ne discomfite lord beloved citizen people nowe sir third point whereas olde wise counsaylours saied yt ye ought suddainly ne hastily proceed need yee ought purueyen apparaile case great dilligence deliberation verely trow saied right truly right sooth tullius sayth every deed thou begin apparaile thee great diligence say vengeaunce taking war battaile warnestoring thou begin rede thou apparaile thee thereto great deliberation tullius sayth long apparailing tofore battaile maketh short victorie cassidorus sayth garrison stronger long time avised let u speake counsayle accorded neighbour done reverence withouten love old enemy reconciled flatterer counsailed certain thing prively openly counsailed contrarie young folke also counsailed venge make warre anon certes sir saied ye greatly erred clepe manner folke counsaile counsailours ben ynough reproued reason aforesaid nathelesse let u descend special ye shull first proceed doctrine tullius certes trouth matter counsaile needeth diligently enquire wel wist han done trespas villanie many trespassours manner done wrong villany shull ye examine second condition tullius addeth matter tullius putteth thing clepeth consenting say ben many consenten thy counsaile thy wilfulnesse done hastie vengeaunce let u consider also many consented adversary first point well knowen folke consented hastie wilfulnesse truly tho counsaile maken suddaine warre ne friend let see beene ye holden greatly friend person albeit ye mighty rich certes ye alone truly yee ne child doughter ne ye brother ne cousin germaines ne none nigh kinrede wherefore enemy stint plead ne destroy person ye know also rich mote dispended diverse party every wight hath part wollen take little regard venge death thine enemy ben three many brother child cousin nigh kinrede though thou haddest slaine hem two three yet dwelleth ynowe avenge death slea thy person though kinrede stedfast siker kinne adversary yet neverthelesse kinrede kinrede ben little sibbe kinne enemy ben nigh sibbe hem certes condition better let u consider also counsayling hem counsayled take suddaine vengeaunce whether accord reason non certes yee know well nay right reason may man take vengeaunce wight judge hath jurisdiction graunted take vengeaunce hastely attemperately law requireth yet moreover thilke word tullius clepeth consenting thou shalt consent thy might thy power may consent suffice thy wilfulnesse thy counsaylours certes thou mayest well say nay sikerly speake properly may nothing thing may done rightfully certes rightfully ye may take vengeaunce proper authority may ye see power ne consenteth ne accordeth wilfulnesse nowe let u examine third point tullius clepeth consequence thou shalt understond yt vengeaunce thou purposest take consequent thereof followeth another vengeaunce perill warre dammages withouten number wee ware time touching fourth point tullius clepeth engendring thou shalt consider wrong done thee engendred hate thine enemy vengeaunce taking upon hem yt would engender another vengeaunce muckell sorrow wasting richesse sayed ere sir touching fift point tully cleapeth cause last point thou shalt understond wrong thou hast received hath certain cause clerkes callen oryen effycien causa longinqua causa propinqua say ferre cause nigh cause ferre cause almighty god cause thing neere cause three enemy cause accidentall hate cause material ben ye five wound thy doughter cause formall ye maner werking brought ladder clambe thy windowes cause finall slea thy doughter letted much speak ferre cause end come finally shall betide case ne deme conjecting supposing shall suppose shall come wicked end booke decree sayth seld great paine ben cause brought good end ben badly begun sir men would aske god suffred men villany truly cannot well answer soothfastnesse ye apostle sayeth science judgement lord god almightie full deep may man comprehend ne search hem nathelesse certain presumption coniectings hold beleeve god full justice righteousnes hath suffred betide iust cause reasonable thy name melibe say man drinketh honey thou hast dronke much honey sweet temporall richesse delices honour world thou art dronke hast forgotten iesu christ thy creatour thou ne hast doen honour reverence thee ought ne thou ne hast taken keepe ye word ovid sayth vnder ye honey good thy bodie hid ye venome yt slaeth thy soule salomon sayth yt thou hast found honey eat honey sufficeth bee thou eat honey measure thou shalt spewe also needy poore peraventure almightie god iesu christ hath thee dispight hath tourned away fro thee face eares misericorde mercie also hath suffred give licence thou thus shouldest bee punished chastised ye manner thou hast trespassed offended thou hast done sinne lord christ certes three enemy mankind say flesh fiend world thou hast suffered hem entre thine heart wilfully windowes thy body hast defended thy selfe sufficiently ayenst assault temptation wounded thy soule five place say deadly sinnes ben entred thy hart thy five wit manner lorde christ hath would suffered thy three enemy entered thy hous yt windowes wounded thy doughter foresaied manner truly qd melibe see well yee enforce much word overcome manner shall venge mee mine enemy shewing ye peril evil yt might fall vengeaunce would consider vengeance peril evil might sue vengeaunce taking man would never take vengeaunce harme vengeaunce taken ye wicked men discevered fro good men yt doe wickednesse restrain wicked purpose see punishing chastising trespassours yet say mo e right singular person sinneth taking vengeaunce another man right sinneth ye judge doe vengeaunce hem deserved senecke sayeth thus maister sayth good preveth shrew cassiodore saith man dredeth outrage wot knoweth yt displeaseth ye iudges soveraignes another sayth iudge yt dreadeth doe right maketh men shrewes add saint poule apostle sayeth epistle writeth unto romanes iudge bear speare withoutcause beare punish shrewes misdoers defend good men ye woll take vengeaunce enemy ye shull retourne recourse iudge hath jurisdiction upon hem shall punish hem law asketh requireth ha saied melibe vengeaunce liketh nothing bethink take heed fortune hath nourished mee fro childhood hath holpe passe many stronge paas would assay trowing god helpe shall helpe mee shame avenge truly saied prudence yee woll werke counsaile yee shall assay fortune way ne yee shall lean unto word senecke thing foolishly doen done hope fortune shall never come good end ye senek sayth clere shining fortune britle sooner broke trusteth stedfast ne stable thou trowest sure stedfast helpe woll faile deceive thee whereas ye say fortune hath nourished fro childhood say much ye shall lesse trust wit seneke saith man yt nourished fortune maketh great foole sith ye desire aske vengeaunce vengeaunce done law judge ne liketh vengeaunce doen hope fortune perillous uncertaine yee none remedie haue recourse vnto soveraine iudge vengeth villanies wrong shall venge witnesseth whereas saith leave vengeaunce shall melibeus answerd ne venge ye villanie yt men haue doen summon warne hem haue doen villanie doe another villany written thou take vengeaunce old villany thou summonest thine aduersaries thee new villanie also sufferaunce men would doe much villanie might neither beare ne sustain put holden ouer low men sain mikell suffring shal many thing fall vnto thee thou shalt mow suffer certes qd prudence graunt yt ouermuch suffraunce good yet ne followeth thereof euery person men doe villanie take vengeance appertaineth longeth onely iudges venge ye villanies iniuries therefore two authority yee haue saied beene onely vnderstond iudges suffer ouermuch wrong villanies bee doen withouten punishment summon man onely doe newe wrong commaund also wise
