betwixt hem two iason shall wedde true knight terme yset come soone night vnto chambre make othe vpon goddes lefe lothe ne shulde never falsen night ne day ben husband whyle live may deth saved vpon night mete yfere doth othe gothe bedde morow vpward spedde hath taught shall nat faile flees winne stinten bataile saved life honour gate name conquerour right ye sleight enchantment hath iason flese home went medea treasours fell great wonne vnwist father gonne thessalie duke iason lefe afterward hath broght mischeife traytour go left yong child two falsely hath betraied ala ever love chefe traytour wedded yet thirde wife anon doughter king creon meede loving guerdon medea received duke iason right trouth kindnesse loved better selfe gesse left father heritage iason vassalage dayes na never none yfound salse lover going ground therfore letter thus said first falsenesse vpbraid liked yellow haire see bound mine honestie liked youth thy fairenesse thy tong infinite graciousnesse haddest thou thy conquest dead ybe ful mikel vntrouth diede thee well ovide letter verse endite long write pthe legende lucrece rome mote saine thexiling king rome horrible doings last king tarquinius saith ovid titus liuivs cause tell nat storie praysen drawen memorie wife lucresse wifehood stedfastnesse nat painems commend cleped legend great austyn hath compassioun lucrece starfe rome toun wise woll shortly treat thing touch great ardea besieged romanes yt full sterne stout full long lay siege little wroughten yt halfe idle hem thoughten play tarquinius yong gan yape light tong said idle life man wife let v speke wife best praise every man owne lest speech let v ease hert knight hight collatin vp stert sayd thus nay sir nede trowen word dede wife qd trow holden good ever know go rome night shull see tarquinius answerde liketh mee rome comen fast hem dight colatins house downe light tarquinius eke colatine husbond knew efters well fine full prively house gone gate porter none chamber dore abide noble wife sate bed side discheueled mallice ne thought soft wooll sayth liuie wrought kepe slouth idlenesse bad servaunts done businesse asketh hem tidings heren ye sayth men siege shall god would wals fallen adoun mine husbond long toun drede doth sore smert right sword stingeth mine hert thinke place god save lord pray grace therwithall tenderly gan weepe werke tooke keepe meekely let eyen fall thilke semblant sate well withall eke teares full heavinesse embesessed wifely chastnesse countenaunce hert digne acordeden deed signe word husbond collatin ware came stertling said drede thee nat anone vp rose blisfull chere kissed wife wonne tarquinius proud king sonne conceived hath beautie chere yellow haire bountie manere hew word hath complained craft beautie nat fained caught lady desire hert brent fire woodly wit forgotten well thought nat gotten aye dispaire coveiteth thought faire blind lust coveiring morrow bird began sing vnto siege commeth full prively himselfe walketh soberly image recording alway new thus lay hair thus fresh hew thus sate thus span chere thus fair manere conceit heart hath new itake see tempest shake storme ago yet woll water quappe day two right though forme absent pleasaunce forme present nathelesse nat pleasaunce delite vnrightfull talent dispite maugre shall lemman hap helpeth hardy man alway qd end make shall girt sword gan go forthright till rome come alone way hath nome vnto house colatin full right doun sunne day hath lost light come vnto privie halke night full theefely gan stalke every wight rest brought ne wight treason thought whether window gin swerd ydraw shortly commeth lay noble wife lucresse woke bedde felt presse beast qd wayeth thus king sonne tarquinius qd thou crie noise make thou creature awake thilke god formed man live swerd thine hert shall rive therwithall vnto throte stert set swerd sharpe hert word spake hath might therto shall saine wit ago right wolfe findeth lamb alone shall complaine make mone shall fight hardy knight well wote men woman hath might shall crie shall astert hath ye throte swerd hert asketh grace said wolt thou nat qd cruell man wisely iupiter soule save shall thy stable slea thy knave lay thy bed loud crie thee find avoutrie thus thou shalt dead also lese thy name thou shalt nat chese roman wife loveden name thilke time dreden shame wt fere slander drede death lost one wit breath swough lay woxe dead men mighten smite arme head feleth nothing neither foule ne faire tarquinius art king heire shouldest linage right done lord knight hast thou done dispite chivalrie hast thou done thy lady villanie ala thee villanous dede purpose story rede gon mischaunce fall lady sent friendes father mother husbond ifere discheveled haire clere habite woman vsed tho vnto burying friend go sate hall sorowfull sight friend asken aylen might dead sate aye weeping word shame ne may forth bring ne vpon hem durst nat behold last tarquiny hem told rufull case thing horrible wo tell impossible friend make one folkes herts ben stone might maked hem vpon rew hert wifely trew said gilt ne blame husbond nat ye foule name would nat suffren way answerde vnto fay foryave right gilt lay nat might saiden ensamples many one naught thus said anone may qd forgiving nat forgift nothing prively cought forth knife therwithall raft selfe life fell adowne cast looke clothes yet heed tooke falling yet care least foot thing lay bare well loved cleannesse eke trouth towne rome routh brutus hath chast blood swore tarquin ybanished therfore kinne let people call openly tale told hem openly let carry bere town men may see horrible deed oppressioun ne never king rome toun sen thilke day holden saint ever day yhallowed dere law thus endeth lucresse noble wife titus beareth witnesse tell love trew ne chaunged new stable hert sadde kind woman men may day find cast hert dwelleth well wote christ himselfe telleth israel wide lond great faith lond ne fond woman lie men looke ye tyrannie doen day assay hem list truest full brothell trist pthe legend ariadne athens jvdge infernall minos crete king commeth thy lot thou commest ring nat thy sake written storie clepe ayen vnto memorie theseus great vntrouth love god heaven ben wroth wrath take thy sinne red shame thy life beginne minos mighty king crete hundred city strong grete schoole hath sent sonne androgeus athens happed thus slaine learning phylosophie right citie nat envie great minos speke sonnes death come wreke alcathoe besieged hard long nathelesse walles strong nisus king cite chivalrous little dredeth minos hoast tooke cure till day befell aventure nisus doughter stood vpon wall siege saw manner happed scarmishing cast hert vpon minos king beautie chevalrie sore wende die shortly processe pace made minos winnen thilke place citie saven list el spill wickedly quit kindnesse let drench sorrow distresse nere god pite tale long athene wan king minos also alcathoe townes mo effect minos hath driven hem athene mote yeven fro yere yere owne child dere slaine ye shall minos hath monster wicked best cruell without areest man brought presence would eat helpeth defence every third yeare withouten dout casten lotte came rich poore must sonne take childe must present make minos save spill let beast devour hath minos done right dispite wreke sonne set delite make hem athene thrall fro yere yere liven shall home saileth toun wicked custome long yron till athene king egeus mote senden owne sonne theseus sen lotte fallen vpon ben devoured grace non forth ladde wofull yong knight vnto ye country king minos full might prison fettred fast till time yfreten well maist thou wepe wofull theseus art king sonne damned thus thinketh thou art depe yhold saved thee fro care cold woman helpe thee well oughtest thou servaunt bee ben true lover yere yere come ayen matere toure theseus throw bottome derk wonder low joyning wall foreine longing vnto doughtren tweine minos chamber grete dwelten maister strete towne joy sollas nat happed percaas theseus complained night king doughter ariadne hight eke suster phedra herden complaint stood wall looked vpon bright moone hem list nat go bed soone wo compassion king sonne prison ben devoured thought hem great pite ariadne spake suster free said phedra lefe suster dere wofull lord sonne may ye nat pitously complaineth kin eke poore estate guiltlesse certes routh ye woll assent trouth shall ben holpen phedra answerde iwis wo ever man helpe best rede done gailer prively come speke v hastely done wofull man come may monster overcome quit none boot let v well tast hart root weapon life dare kepe save fighten fiend defend prison shall discend ye wote well beast place derke hath roume eke space welde axe swerde staffe knife thinketh save life man shall shall make balles eke also towe gapeth fast beestes throte shall hem cast sleke honger encomber teeth right anon theseus seeth beest acheked shall leepe sleen comen heepe apen shal gailer tide full prively within prison hide house crencled fro hath queint way go shapen mase wrought thereto remedy thought clewe twine hath gon way may returne anon folowing alway threde hath come beest overcome may flien away stede eke gailer may lede avaunce home countre sen great lord sonne rede ye dare take shold lenger sermon make gailer cometh theseus thing ben accorded thus downe sate theseus vpon knee right lady life qd sorowfull man ydamned deth fro while lasteth breth wol nat twinne aventure service thus woll endure wretch vnknow woll serve forevermore till mine hert sterve forsake woll home mine heritage said ben court page ye vouchsafe place ye graunt soche grace may nat meate drinke sustinaunce yet woll swinke right list minos ne wight sen saw never eyen sight ne man el shall espie slily well shal gie wel disfigure low world shall man know life presence done excellence father shall sende worthy man gaylere guerdon shall well one greatest men countre durst saine lady bright king sonne eke knight wold god might ye countrey thre beare companie shuld ye sene thereof lie profer lowe manere ben page serven right serve lowly place pray mar yeve soch grace shame death mote fall death poverte frends sprite night mote go death walke fro mote traitour name sprit mote go shame clayme ever degree ye vouchsafe yeve mee said shame death dey mercy lady naught el sey semely knight theseus see yonge twenty yere three ysene countenance wold wept routh penance ariadne manere answerde profre chere king sonne eke knight qd go ben servaunt lowe degree god shilde shame woman lene never soch case befall sende grace sleight hert also defend knightly sleen foe lene hereafter may find suster kind ne repent nat yeve life yet better wife sith ye ben gentill borne realme nat fast suffred gentillesse sterve let page serve profite vnto kinrede man woll nat dred suster sith mote gone go el suffre death wel ye vnto sonne trewly done wedded home coming finall end thing ye swere vpon may sworne ye lady mine qd el torne mote minotaure morow haveth mine hert blood borow ye woll knife speare would letten thereon sweare erste wot ye would leve mar chiefe beleve might liven nat faile morow taken bataile nolde never fro place flie till ye profe se soth shall say loved full many day though ye ne wist nat countre aldermost desired see earthly living creature vpon truth sweare assure seven yere servaunt also ye dere hert athene duchesse lady smileth stedfastnesse hartely wordes chere luster said manere sothly suster mine qd duchess ye sikerde regals athene hereafter likely queenes saved fro death king sonne ever gentill woman wonne save gentil man enforth might honest cause namely right thinketh wight ought v blame ne bearen v therefore yvel name shortly mater make theseus hath leave ytake every point performed dede ye covenaunt herde rede wepen clewe thing yt said gailer house ylaid minotaure hath dwelling right fast dore entring theseus lad vnto dethe forth vnto minotaure gethe teaching adriane overcame beest bane cometh clewe againe ful prively beest hath slaine gailer gotten hath barge wife treasure gan charge toke wife eke suster free gailer hem al three stole away lond night countre enupie dight frende knowing feesten daunsen sing armes hath adriane beest hath kept fro bane get noble barge anone countrey folke ful great wone taketh leave homeward saileth hee yle amidde wilde see dwelt creature none save wild beestes full many one made shippe londe sette yle halfe day lett e said londe must rest mariner done right lest tell shortly caas ariadne wife slepe suster fayrer taketh honde forth goeth ship traitour stale away ariadne slepe lay countrey warde sailed blive twenty divel way winde drive found father drenched see liste speke parde false lover poison bane wol turne againe adriane slepe werinesse ytake ful sorowfully hert may awake ala thee mine herte hath pite right dawning awaketh gropeth bed fond right nought ala qd ever wrought betrayed heere rent stronde barefote fast went cried theseus mine hert swete ye may nat mete might thus beestes ben yslaine halow rockes answerde againe man saw yet shone moone hie vpon rocke went soone sawe barge sayling see cold woxe hert right thus said meker ye find beestes wilde hath nat sinne thus begilde cried turne againe routhe sinne thy barge hath nat meine kerchefe pole sticked ascaunce well yse remembre behind turne againe stronde find naught way gone downe fel swowne stone vp riste kissed care steppe feete hath fare bed right thus speketh tho thou bed qd hast received two thou shalt answere two one greater parte away gone ala wher shal wretched wight become though bote none come home countrey dare nat drede selfe case nat rede tell complaining long heavy thing epistle naso telleth shortly end tell shall goddes holpen pite signe taurus men may see stone crowne shine clere speake matere thus false lover begile trew love divel quite wile pthe legende philomene thou yever ye formes yt hast wrought fayre world bare thy thought eternally er thou thy werke began madest thou vnto slaunder man thy end make soch thing suffredest thou tereus bore love false forswore fro world vp first heven corrumpeth yt folke name neven grisly dede foule storie rede mine iyen wexen foule sore also yet lasteth venime longe ago enfecteth wolde behold storie tereus told trace lord kin marte cruel god stante blody darte wedded blisfull chere king pandionis faire doughter dere hight progne floure countre though iuno list feast ne himeneus god wedding feast ready ben iwis fury three mortall bronde oule night balkes wonde prophete wo mischaunce revell full song full daunce last fourtenight little lasse shortly storie passe weary tell five yere wife togither dwell till day gan sore long seene suster saw long desire nist say husbond gan pray god love mote one gone suster seene come ayen anone el mote wend praied would send day day prayere al himblesse wifehood word chere tereus let make ship yare grece himselfe forth ifare vnto father law gan pray vouchsafe moneth tway philomene wife suster might progne wife one sight shall come anon selfe come gon herts life kepe old pandion king gan wepe tendernesse hert leve doughter gon yeve leve world loved nothing last leave hath go philomene salt teares eke gan father grace beseke seene suster longeth enbraceth armes two also yong faire tereus saw beaute array none liche yet beautie riche cast fierie hert vpon woll go wile kneled praied till last pandion thus saied sonne qd art dere thee betake yong doughter dere beareth key mine herts life grete well doughter thy wife yeve leave sometime pley may seen one deie sothly hath made riche feast folke eke least came yave yefts great conveieth master streat athene sea brought tourneth home malice ne thought ore pulleth forth vessell fast trace arriveth last vp forest led cave prively sped darke cave lest list nought bad rest herte agrose saied thus suster brother tereus therewithall wept tenderly quoke feare pale pitiously right lambe wolfe bitten culver egle smitten claves forth escaped yet aferde waped lest hent eftsones sate sehe vtterly may none force hath traitour done deede hath reft maidenhede maugre head strength might lo deede men aright crieth suster full loude steven father dere helpe god heven helpeth yet false thefe hath done lady yet mischefe feare lest shame crie done openly villanie sweard tong kerfe castell made full prively prison evermore kept vsage store ne might never astarte sely philomene wo thine hart huge thy sorowes wonder smart god wreke thee sende thee thy bone time make end sone tereus wife icome armes hath wife inome pitiously wept shoke hedde swore found suster dedde selie progne hath soch wo nigh sorowfull hert brake two thus teares let progne dwell suster forth woll tell wofull lady ilearned youth worken enbrauden couth weaven stole rade vore woman hath woved yore sothly saine hath fill meate drinke clothing couthe eke rede well inough endite penne could write letter weave fro yere ago woven stames large brought fro athens barge cave brought thing tereus wrought wave wel wrote storie served susters love man ring yave anon praied signes gon vnto queene bearen clothe signe swore many othe yeve getten might man anon vnto quene dight toke maner told progne hath thing behold worde spake sorow eke rage fained gon pilgrimage baccus remple little stound dombe suster sitting hath found weeping castell selfe alone ala wo constraint mone progne vpon dombe suster maketh armes everich hem taketh thus let hem sorow dwell remnaunt charge tell thus served never agilt ne deserved vnto cruell man wist ye may beware men list woll shame doen tereus lese name ne serve murtherer knave full little shull ye trewe wol sain al brother may another pthe legende phillis prove wel aucthorite wicked fruicte commeth wicked tree may ye find liketh end speake tell false demophon love falser heard never non father theseus god grace fro soch one kepe v thus woman praied effect tourne matere destroied troie citee demopon came sayling see toward athene paleis large came many ship many barge full folke full many one wounded sore sicke wo begone siege long ilaine behind came winde eke raine shofe sore saile might stonde lever world londe hunteth tempest fro darke could go wave brusten stere ship rent lowe manere carpenter could amende see night torche brende wood posseth vp doun till neptune hath compassioun thetis chorus triton maden vp londe fall wherof phillis lady queene lycurgus doughter fairer vnto seene floure bright sonne vnneth demophon londe iwonne weake eke werie folke forpined werinesse also enfamined death almost idriven wise folke counsaile yeven seken helpe succour queene loken grace might bene maken lande chevesaunce kepen fro wo fro mischaunce sicke almost death vnneth might speake draw breath lieth rhodopeia rest may walk thought best vnto countrey seeken succour men knew wele honour athene duke lord theseus father hath ibe time great renoun man great regioun like father face stature false love came nature doth foxe renarde fox sonne kind could old father wonne without lore drake swimme caught caried brimme honorable queen phillis doth chere liketh well sporte manere agroted beforne write hem love forsworne eke haste legende performe god grace sende therfore passe shortly wise ye well heard theseus gise betraiyng faire adriane pite kept fro bane short wordes right demophon way pathe hath gon false father theseus vnto phillis hath sworne thus wedden trouth plight piked good might hole sound rest doth phillis lest well could list tellen fro sayd countrey mote saile would wedding apparaile fill honour also openly tooke leave tho swore would sojourne month would retourne londe let make ordinaunce lorde tooke obeisaunce well humbly shippes dight home goeth next way might vnto phillis yet came nought hath harde sore ibought ala storie doth v record owne death corde saw demophon traied first wrote fast praied would come deliver pain rehearse shall worde twain liste vouchsafe swinke dispenden penne full ynke false love right sire devill set soules fire letter phillis woll write worde twain although lite thine hostesse qd demophon thy phillis wo begon rhodopeie vpon mote complain terme set betwixt v twain ye ne holden forward ye sayd ancre ye layd hight v ye would comen doubt moone one went time fower moone hath hid face sen thilke day ye went fro place fower time light world yet shall sothly sain yet hath streme scython brought athens ship yet came nought ye terme reken would true lover doe plain god wot day al letter writen ne may order charge letter right long therto large rime layd thought hath wel sayd sayd sailes cometh ne worde ni ey certain wot ye come qd love fre goddes ye swore vengeaunce fall therfore ye suffisaunt beare pain moche trusted well may sain vpon linage faire tong teares falsly wrong coud ye wepe craft qd may soche teares fained certes ye would memory ought little glory selie maide thus betrayed god qd pray oft prayed greatest price honour ever shall befall thine old aunceters painted bee men may worthinesse see pray god thou painted also folke may reden forth go lo flattery betraied hath done villany true love thought dede sothly point yet may rede ye like father begiled ariadne iwis arte subtelte thou thy self hast begiled poinct although feire thou folowest certain art heire sen thus sinfully ye begile body mote ye sene within right athene fleeting withouten sepulture buriyng though ye harder stone letter forth sent anone knew brotell fals dispaire fordid selfe ala sorow hath beset beware ye woman subtill fo sen yet day men may ensample se trusteth love man pthe legende hypermestre grecen whilom brother two one called danao many son hath body wonne soch false lover ofte conne emong sonnes one aldermost loved everychone child borne danao shope name called lino brother called egiste love false ever liste many daughter gate life gate vpon right wife doughter dere call hypermestra yongest hem child nativite good thewes borne liked goddes borne shefe corne werdes clepen destine hath shapen must needes pitous sad wise true stele woman accordeth wele though venus yave great beaute iupiter compowned conscience trouth drede shame wifehode kepe name thought felicite reed mar time yere feble malice raft repressed hath venus cruell craft venus oppression house mar venime hypermestre dare handle knife malice though lese life nathelesse heaven gan tho turne two bad aspectes hath saturne made die prison shall make mencion danao cgistes also though brother two thilke tyme na spared linage liked hem maken mariage betwixt hypermestre lino casten soch day shall full accorded vtterly aray wrought tyme fast thus lino hath father brother doughter wedded ech hem hath torch brennen ye lamp bright sacrifice full ready dight thensence fire reketh soote floure leefe rent vp roote maken garlandes crounes hie full place sound minstralcie songes amourous mariage thilke tyme plain vsage paleis egiste hous lord right liste thus day driven end frendes taken leve home wend night come bride shall go bed egiste chamber fast sped prively let doughter call house voided hem looketh doughter glad chere spake ye shall right doughter tresour mine hert sen first day shapen shert fatall suster dome nie mine hert never thing ne come thou hypermestre doughter dere take hede thy father sayth thee werke thy wiser ever mo alderfirst doughter love thee world ni halfe lefe ne nolde rede thee thy mischefe good vnder cold mone meane shall said right sone protestacion saine wise thou doe shall thee devise thou shalt ded al hath wrought short wordes thou ne scapest nought paleis thou deed thou consent werke reed take fearfull conclusioun hypermestre cast iyen doun quoke doth leefe ashe grene deed wext hew like ashen sene sayd lord father might god wote fulfill confusion nill qd none excepcion caught knife rasour kene hide qd isene thine housbond bed go slepeth cut throte atwo dreme warned nevewe shall bane wherfore woll siker thou say nay two shall biker sayd sworn hipermestre hath nigh wit forlorn passen harmelesse place graunted ther none grace withall costrell taketh tho sayd hereof draught two yeve drinke goeth rest shal slepe long ever thee lest narcotikes apies strong go thy way lest thinke long cometh bride full sobre chere maiden oft manere chamber brought revel song shortly leste tale long lino beth brought bed every wight doore sped night wasted fell aslepe full tenderly beginneth weepe rist vp dredfully quaketh doth braunch zephirus shaketh husht aragone citee colde frost wexeth shee pite herte strained drede death doth moche wo thrise doune fill soche riste vp stakereth hand fast looketh ala shall mine hand bloudie maide nature semblaunt vesture mine hand shapen knife reve man fro life devill knife shall throte corve two shall blede ala shende nedes thing mote ende mote nedes lese life certes qd sen wife hath faith yet bette dedde wifely honeste traitour living shame may earnest game shall awake rise go way gutter er day wept full tenderly vpon face armes gan embrace joggeth awaketh soft window lepe fro loft hath warned done bote lino swift light foote ran full good paas selie woman weake ala helplesse er ferre went cruell father hent ala lino art thou vnkind ne hast thou remembred thy mind taken led forth thee saw gone away hee might fast go ne folowen sate doune right tho vntill caught fettred prison tale sayd conclusion phere endeth legende good woman pa goodly ballade chaucer mother norture best beloved freshe floure good thrift god sende childe luste call vnable selfe pretende discrecion recommende mine herte al every circumstaunce wholly vnder governaunce desire ever shal thing might herts ease amend excused power small nathelesse right ye ought commend good faine would entend service suffisaunce holly vnder governaunce meulx vn hert never shall apall aie freshe new right glad dispend time service befall beseching excellence defend simplenesse ignoraunce offend wise sith mine affiaunce holly vnder governaunce daisie light ground comfort sunnes doughter ye hight rede westreth farwell disport nature anone right pure drede rude night yt boistous wede darkenesse shadoweth emispere closen ye life ladie dere dauning day kind resort phebus father streames rede adorneth morrow consuming sort mistie cloudes woulden overlede true humble herts mistie hede nere comfort day iyen clere disclose sprede life ladie dere ie vouldray great god disposeth maketh casuel providence soch thing man frele wit purposeth best conscience grutche humble pacience receive god saith without fable faithful hert ever acceptable cautels vseth gladly gloseth eschewe soch right high prudence ye sayd one mine hart opposeth writing yapes absence pleased moch better presence yet ye excusable faithfull harte ever acceptable quaketh penne spirit supposeth writing ye find woll offence min hert welkneth thus sone anon riseth hotte colde eft feruence misse caused negligence malice therefore beth merciable faithfull harte ever acceptable plenuoye forth complaint forth lacking eloquence forth little letter enditing lame besought lady sapience thy behalfe accept game thine inabilitie doe thou abide yet ie serve iouesse forth close thee holy venus name thee shall vnclose hart governeresse boecius de consolatione philosophiae book handled high hard obscure point viz purveyance god force destiny freedom will infallible prescience almighty contemplation god summum bonunt carmina qui quondam studio florenti peregi flebilis heu moestos coger inire modos ala weeping constrained begin verse sorrowful matter whilom florishing studie made delitable ditees lo rending mus poet enditen thing written drerie teates laste drede ne might overcome tho mus ne werren fellowes folowden way say exiled youth whilom weelful grene comforten sorowful wierdes old man elde commen unwarely vpon hasted harmes sorrow hath commaunded age heeres hore shad overtimeliche vpon head stacke skinne trembleth mine empted body thilke death menne weleful ne commeth yeres swet commeth wretch often leped ala ala deafe eare death cruell turneth away wretch aieth close weepying iyen fortune vnfaithfull fauoured light goodes sorowful houre say death almost dreint mine hedde fortune cloudie hath chaunged deceiueable chere meward mine vnpitous life draweth along vngreable dwelling ye frends whereto auaunted ye wilfull hath fallen stode stedfast degree haec dum mecum tacitus ipse reputarem querimoniamque lacrimabilem stili officio designarem astitisse mihi supra verticem visa est mulie reverendi admodum vultus oculis ardentibus ultra communem c mean stil recorded thynges self marked wepely complainte office poinctell saugh stondyng abouen hight mine hed woman full great reuerence semblant iyen brennyng clere seyng ouer common might men liuely colour soch vigour strength ne might nempned full great age menne woulden trowen manere elde stature doutous iudgement sometime constrained shronke seluen like common measure men sometime seemed touched heaven ye hight hedde houe hedde higher perced ye selfe heauen sight men looking idell clothes maked right delie thredes subtell craft per durable mattier clothes shee wouen owne honds knew well selfe declaring shewing beauty clothes darkenesse forleten dispised elde dusked darked wonte darke smoked image netherest hemme border clothes men redde iwouen therein grekish signifieth life actiue aboue letter hiest bordure grekish c signifieth lyfe contemplatife betwene two letter seen degree nobly wrought maner ladder degree men might climben netherest letter ye vpperest nathelesse handes men hadden kerue cloth violence strength eueriche man hem borne away peces might getten forsothe foresaid woman bare small bookes right hand left hand bare scepter sawe poeticall mus approching bed endityng wordes wepinges little amoued glowe cruell iyen qd hath suffred approchen sicke man commen strompets place men callen theatre onely ne asswagen sorrowes remedy would feden norish swete venime forsoth tho thornes pricking talentes affection nothing fructuous profitable distroyen come plentuous fruictes reason holden harte men vsage ne deliuer folke fro malady mus withdrawen fro flattery vnconnyng vnprofitable man wont finde commenly among people would well suffre lasse greuously soche vnprofitable man myne entente nothyng endammaged ye withdrowen fro man hath norished study scoles eleaticis achademicis grece goeth rather away yee metmaydens swete till last suffreth man cured healed mus yt say notefull science thus company mus iblamed casten wrothly chere douneward yearth shewing rednesse shame passeden sorowfully threshold sight plounged teares darked ne might know woman imperiall aucthoritie wo e abashed astonied cast sight doune yearth began still abide would doen afterward came nere set doune vpon vtterest corner bed beholding chere cast yearth heauy greuous weeping complained wordes shall aine perturbation thought heu quam praecipiti mersa profundo men habet propria luce relicta tendit ad externas ire tenebras terrenis quoties flatibus acta crescit immensum noxia cura hic quondam coelo liber aperto c ala thought manne dreinte ouerthrowing depenesse dulleth foreleteth proper cleerenesse mintyng gone forayne darknesse oft anoious besinesse wexeth without measure yt driuen worldly windes manne whilome free whome heauen open knowen wont gone heauenly pathes sawe lightnesse redde sunne beheld ye sterres cold moone sterre heauen vseth wandring recourse lit diuers sphere man ouercomer comprehended al thing nomber accompting astronomie ouer hee wont seken cause whence ye sowning windes mouen besien smothe water sea spirite tourneth stable heauen sterre riseth red east fallen westren waues attempreth lustie houres ye first sommer season highteth apparayleth yearth rosie floures maketh plumtuous autumpne full yeres fleeten heauie grape eke manne wont tell diuers cause nature hidde ala lightly empted light thought necke pressed heauy chaines beareth chere enclined adoune ye great weight constrained looken foolish yearth sed magi medicinae inquit tempus est quam querelae boe tum vero totis intenta luminibus philo tu ne ille e ait qui nostro quondam lacte nutritus nostris educatus alimentis virilis animi robur evaseras c time medicine qd complaint forsooth shee entending mewarde ye lookyng iyen saied art nat thou qd yt whilom nourished milke fostred meat escaped commen courage parfite man certes yaue thee soche armour thou thy self ne haddest first cast hem away shoulden haue defended thee sikernesse may ouercomen knowest thou art thou stil shame astoniyng leuer shame seemeth astoniyng hath oppressed thee sawe onely still rather without office tongue dombe layed hand softely breast saied perill qd fallen litarge common sicknesse harte deceiued hath little foryeten himselfe certes shall lightly remembren hath knowen er may doen wipe iyen little darked cloud mortall thing wordes saied lappe garment iplited frounce dried mine iyen full waues weeping tunc discussa liquerunt nocte tenebre luminibusque prior redit vigor ut cum praecipiti glomerantur sidera choro nimbosisque polus stetit imbribus sol later ac nondum coelo venientibus astris c thus night discussed away darknesse forlette iyen repaired againe first strength right ensample ye sunne hidde sterres couered cloud swift wind hight chorus firmament stant derked plungy cloud sterres apperen vpon ye heauen night semed sprad vpon yearth wind hight boreas isent caue country trace beateth night saine chaseth away discouereth closed day shineth phebus ishaked sodaine light smiteth beam marueyling iyen haud aliter tristitiae nebulis dissolutis hausi coelum ad cognoscendam medicantis faciem mentem recepi itaque ubi eam deduxi oculos intuitum que defixi respicio nutricem meam cujus ab adolescentia c right none otherwise cloudes sorrowe dissolued doen awaie tooke heauen receyued mynd knowen face phisicien sette myne iyen vpon fastened looking beheld nourice philosophie whose house conuersed fro youth saied thus thou maistresse vertues discended soueraine seate art thou commen solitarie place myne exile art thou commen thou art made coulpable false blame qd nourice forsake thee parten thee commen trauayle charge thou haste suffered enuie name certes lefull ne fitting philosophie leten without companie way innocent shold redout blame agrise though befallen new thing trowest thou philosophie alderfirst assayled perilles folke wicked maner striuen full grate strife old time age plato ayenst foolehardinesse foly eke plato liuyng maister socrates deserued victorie vnrightfull death presence heritage socrates heritage saine doctrine socrates opinion felicite yt cleape welefulness people epicuriens stoiciens many enforced go ravish every many parte saine ye everich hem would drawen defence opinion wordes socrates partie praie droune criyng debating ayenst coruen renten clothes wouen mine owne handes tho clothes araced clothes wenten away wening gone hem euery dele epicuriens stoiciens moch semed trace steppe habite folie wenyng tho epicuriens stoiciens familiers peruerted ye errour wicked multitude hem sain semed philosopher pursued death slaine thou haste knowen exiling anaxagoras ne enpoysoning socrates ne tourments zeno straungers yet mightest thou haue knowen seneca canios soranos folke renome neither ouer olde ne vnsolempne whiche men nothing el ne brought death onely enformed maners semeden vnlike study wicked folk thy thou oughtest wondren though bitter sea driuen tempest blowing whiche moste purpose saine displeasen wicked men whiche shrewes hoste neuer great dispise governed leader reason rauished onely fletyng errour folily aud lightly sometyme make hooste ayenst v assaile v strenger leader draweth together riches toure ententife sarpleris sachelles vnprofitable taken high abouen siker tumulte woode noyse warenestored enclosed soche paleis whither clatering anoiyng folie may attaine scorne soch raveners henters foulest thing quisquis composito serenus evo fatum sub pedibus egit superbum fortunam que tuens utram que rectus invictum potuit tenere vultum c clear vertue sad well ordinate living hath put vnder foote proude wierdes looketh vpright vpon eyther fortune hee may holden chere vndiscomfited rage ne manaces sea commoving chasing vnware heate bottome ne shall move man ne vnstable mountaigne hight vesenus writheth broken chimeneis smoking fire ne way thonder leites wonte smiten high coures ne shall move man whereto wretch drede ye tyrant wood felonnous strength hope nothing ne drede thou shalt thou disarmen ye ire thilke vnmighty tiraunt quaking dredeth desireth thing stable right man doeth hath cast away shilde remoued fro place enlaseth chaine may drawen sentis ne inquit haec atque animo illabuntur tuo expers ne e lyrae quid fles quid lachrimis manas si operam medicantis expectas oportet ut vulnus detegas tuum c felest thou qd shee thing entren aught thy courage art thou like asse harp wepest thou spillest thou teares thou abidest helpe leche thee behoveth discover thy wound tho gathered strength courage aunswered sayd needeth qd rehearsing amonicion sheweth inough himselfe sharpenes wexeth woode mee ne moueth thee see face maner place librarie thou haddest chosen right certaine liege thee mine hous thou disputest oft science thing touching diuinite touching mankinde mine habite soche face chere soche sought secretes nature thou enformedest maners reason al lyfe thensample thorder heauen guerdon referre thee obeysaunt certes thou enformedest ye mouth plato sentence saine comen thing communalties blisful studied fully wisedome gouerneden thilke thinges el befell yt gouernours communalties studien get wisedome thou saidest eke ye mouth sayd plato necessarie cause wisemen taken desiren gouernaunce comen thinges ye governaunce citees ileft handes felonous tourmentors citizeins ne shoulden bringen pestilence distruction good folke therefore followyng thilke authours desired put foorth execucion act commen administracion thilke thing yt learned thee emong secrete vesting while thou god put thought wise folke knowen nothing ne brought mastrie dignitie common studie goodness therefore commeth wicked folke haue greuous discordes ne mighten bee released prayer libertie hath freedome conscience ye wrathe mighty folke hath alway dispised sauacion right oft resisted withstand ye man hight canigast made alway thassaut ayenst ye prosper fortune poore feoble folke oft eke put cast triguill prouost ye king hous bothe wrong begon doen eke fully performed often haue couered defended aucthoritie put ayenst peril yt saine put myne aucthoritie perill wretched poore folke couetise straungers vnpunished turmenteden alway miseases greuaunces number neuer man yet drowe fro right wrong sawe fortune riches people prouinces harmed amenused eyther priuy rauenes commen tribute cariages sory suffreden harme glose theoderike king gothes dedde year garner full corn commaunded man buye corne till corne sold greuous dear price beoce withstood ye ordinaunce ouercame knowing al ye king theodorike himselfe coempcion say commen achate buiyng together yt established vpon people soch maner imposicion bought bushel corne must yeuen king ye fiueth parte cextus ye sore hongry time established greuous vnprofitable coempcion men seen well greatly tourmenten endomagen prouince campaine tooke strise ayenst ye prouost pretorie ye common profite ye knowyng ouercame coempcion asked ne tooke effect pauline counsailour roome riches whiche pauline hondes paleis say officer woulden haue deuoured hope couetise yet drowe jowes hem gapeden much payne ye accusacion adiudged beforne ne sodainly henten ne punishen wrongfully albine counsailour roome putte ayenst hate indignacions accusour cyprian inough sen haue purchased great discord ayenst self ought assured ayenst folke ye loue right wisenesse neuer reserued nothing self hemward king hall siker tho accusours accusing condempned nomber accusours one basilius whilome chased king seruice compelled accusing name need foraine money also opilion gaudencius haue accused mee iustice regall whilome deemed theim bothe gon exile tretcheries fraudes without number judgement nolden obey defended hem sikernesse holy house sain fledden seintewarie apperceyued ye king commaunded auoyded citee rauenne certayne day assigned men marken hem forehedde hote yron chasen hem toun thing seemeth might likened cruelty certes day receyued accusing name thilke accusoures may saied hereto hath studie coning deserued thus el foresaied dampnacion made rightful accusours fortune ashamed certes fortune ben ashamed innocence accused yet ought haue shame filth mine accusours aske thou gilte accused men saine would sauen company ye senatours desirest thou heren maner accused distourbed ye accusour bearen letter hee haue made senatours giltie ayenst king royall majestie maistresse demest thou shal forsake blame ne shame thee certes haue would say sauacion ye senate ne shall neuer let wilne confesse know entente accusour distourbed shall cease shall clepe felony sinne haue desired sanacion order senate certes thilk senate doen decretes judgment though sinne felony wilne sauacion folie lieth alway may chaunge merite thing ne trow judgement socrates lefull hide sooth ne assent leasings certes howsoeuer putte gessen prisen judgement thee wise folke thing ye ordinaunce sooth much folk ben comen day shall knowenit haue putte scripture remembraunce touchyng letter falsely made letter accused haue hoped freedome rome wt appertaineth speaken thereof letter fraud shewed apertly libertie haue vsed confession mine accusours thing need hath great strength freedom may men hopen certes would freedom might hoped would haue answered word man hight camus accused canius cesar germanes sonne knowing consenting coniuration made ayenst canius aunswered thus wist thou haddest wist thing sorrow hath dulled witte plaine onely shreud folke apparailen fellonies vertue wonder greatly may perform thyngs haue hoped doen ne ne shreudnesse commeth perauenture defaut like monster maruail ye present sight god may atcheued performed thyngs euery fellonous manne hath conceyued thought innocent thing one thy familiers vnskilfully asked thus god whence commen wicked thing al leful fellonous folk desiren blood death good men eke senate haue wilned gone destroyen haue seen alway batailen defenden good men eke senate deserued father sain senatours shoulden destruction thou remembrest wel gesse would doen sain thing thou thy selfe alway present ruledest citie verone king gredie common slaughter cast transporten vpon order senate guilt royal maiestie gilt albin accused great sikernesse peril defended senate thou wotest well say sooth ne ne auaunted neuer praysing self alway wight receiueth precious renome auaunting werkes amenuseth secree conscience thou mayest well seene end comen mine innocencie receiue paine false fellonie guerdoun vertue open confession fellome euer iudges accordaunt crueltie sain mine accusing hath eyther errour man wit el condition fortune vncertain unto mortal folke ne submitted hem say ne enclined iudge haue pitie compassion although accused would brenne holy house strangle priest wicked swearde greithed death good men algates sentence punished present confessed conuict remoued ye citie rome almost fiue hundred thousand paas without defence dampned proscription death study bounty haue doen senate well worthy merite sayeth nay might yet neuer none hem conuict blame mine trespace mine accusours seen full well ye dignitie would darken medling fellonie baren hond sayd pollute defouled conscience sacriledge couetise dignitie certes thou thy self art planted chasedest siege courage couetise mortal thing ne sacriledge ne leaue haue place thine eyen thou droppedest euery day mine ear thought thilke commandment pythagoras say menne shall seruen god goddes ne conuenient ne none need taken help foulest spirit thou hast ordained set excellence thou madest like god ouer right clean secret chamber mine house say wife companie mine honest friend wiues father well holy worthy reuerenced deed defenden al suspection blame oh malice accusen taken philosophy faith great blame trowen haue affinitie malefice enchauntment replenished fulfilled thy teaching enformed thy maners thus sufficeth thy reuerence ne auail naught thou thy free rather blemished mine oftencion certes harm haue betideth yet encrease harm guessing iudgement much folke ne looken nothing ye desert thing auenture fortune iudgen thing ben purueyed god temporal wilfulnesse commaundeth glosa thus wight haue prosperity good man worthy haue prosperitie hath aduersitie wicked man god hath forsake worthy haue aduersitie opinion folke thereof commeth good gessing first thing forsaked wretch certes greeueth think right diuers sentence people sayth thus much say last charge contrarious fortune blame laied upon caitife men wenen hath deserued suffereth put away good men dispoyled dignity defouled name gessing haue suffred turments good deed certes seemeth see felonous couines wicked men habounden ioy gladnesse see euery lorell shapeth find new fraudes accuse good folk see good folk ouerthrown drede peril euery luxurious tourmentour dare doen fellonie unpunished excited yefts innocent dispoiled sikernesse defence therto list crien god manner stelliferi conditor orbis qui perpetuo nixus solio rapido coelum turbine versas legemque pati sidera cogis ut nunc pleno lucida cornu totis fratris obvia flammis condat stella luna minores nunc obscuro pallida cornu phoebo proprior lumen perdat c thou maker wheele beareth sterres art fastened thy perdurable chaire turnest heauen rauishing sweigh constrainest sterres suffer thy law moon sometime shining ful horn meeting beames sun brother hideth sterres lesse sometime moon pale dark horn approcheth sun leseth light euin sterre hesperus first time night bringeth first cold arising cometh eft ayen used course pale ye morrow rising sun icleped lucifer thou restrainest day shorter dwelling time cold winter maketh leaues fall thou diuidest swift tide night hote summer commen thy might attempreth variaunt season yeare zepherus debonaire wind bringeth ayen first summer season leaues wind hight boreas hath rest away autumne say last end summer seed sterre hight arcturus sew woxen high corn sterre sirius enchaseth hem nothing unbounden old law ne forletteth werk proper estate thou gouernour gouerning thing certain end refulest thou gouern werks men due manner suffrest thou sliding fortune turneth great enterchaunges thing annoyous paine duly punish felon punisheth innocent folk wicked manner sitten high chaires annoying folke treden unrightfully neck holy men vertue clere shining naturally hid derk derknesses rightfull man beareth paine blame fellons ne forswearing ne fraud couerd kempt false colour ne annoieth shrewdnesse shrewdnesse hem list usen strength reioycen hem put hem soueraigne king people without number dreden thou whatsoeuer thou knittest bond thing look wretched earth men foule partie faire part great werke tourmented see fortune thou gouernor withdraw restraine rauishing flood fasten ferme earth stable thilke bond thou gouernest heauen large haec ubi continuato dolore delatravi illa vultu placido nihilque mei questubus mota phi cum te inquit moestum lachrymantemque vidissem illico miserum exulemque cognovi sed quam id longinquum esser exilium continual sorrowe sobbed broken thinges chere pesible nothing amoved complaint said thus saw thee qd sorrowful weeping wist anon thou wretch exiled wist neuer ferre thine exile thy tale ne yshewed certes thou ferre fro thy countrey thou nart putte thou hast fayled thy way gone amisse thou hast leuer wene thou put thy country hast thou put thy selfe rather wight hath wight thou thy selfe ne might neuer haue done thee thou remember thee countrey thou art borne ni gouerned emperours ne gouernment multitude ye country hem athens one lord one king god lord thy country reioyseth dwelling citizen put hem exile ye lord feeedome gouerned bridle obey iustice hast thou forgotten thilke old law thy citie citie ordained established wight hath leuer found therin eat house el may nat exiled right place contained within paleis thilk city drede may deserue exiled letteth tenhabit forletteth also deserue citezein thilke citie yt say face place ne moueth mikell thine owne face ne ne aske rather ye wals thy librarie apparailed wrought yuorie glasse seat thy thoght put nat whilom book put maketh bookes worthy price precious yt say sentence bookes certainly thy desert bestowed common good thou hast said sooth ye multitude thy good deed thou hast said ye honestie ye falsenesse thing ben opposed thee thou hast remembred thing knowne folke felony fraud thine accusours seemeth thee haue touched forsooth rightfully shortly mighten tho thing better plenteously couth mouth people knoweth thou haste eke blamed greatly complained wrongfull deed senate thou hast sorrowed blame thou hast wopen dommage thy renoun apaired thy last sorrow enchased ayen fortune complaynest guerdon ne euenly yolden desert folke thy latter end thy wood muse thou prayedst thilke peace yt governeth heauen governe earth many tribulation affection assailed thee sorrow ire weping draw thee diversly thou art feeble thought mightier remedy ne shullen yet touchen thee wch willen somdele usen lighter medecines thilke passion waxen hard swelling perturbation flowing thy thoght mowen waxe easie soft receiue ye strength mightie eagre medicine easier touching cum phoebi radiis grave cancri sidus inaestuat tum qui largo negantibus sulcis semina credidit elusus cereris fide quarnas pergat ad arbores nunquam purpureum nemus lecturus viola petas c heauie sterre cancre enchaseth beam phebus sayne phebus ye sunne signe cancre yeueth largely seed field refusen receiue hem let gone beguiled trust corne achornes okes thou wilt gather violet ne goe thou nat ye purple wood field chirkinge agriseth colde felenesse winde hight aquilone thou desire wilt vsen grape ne seek thou nat glutton honde strayne presse stalkes vine first summer season bacchus god wine hath rather yeuen yeftes autumne latter ende summer god tokeneth assygneth time abling hem proper office ne suffereth stounds himselfe hath deuided constrayned beene imedled togider thy forletteth certaine ordinaunce ouerthrowing way ne hath glad issue ende werkes primum igitur pateris ne pauculis rogationibus statum tuae mentis attingere atque tentare ut quis modus sit tuae curationis intelligam c first wouldest thou suffer mee touch assay estate thought demaunds yt may understond maner thy curacion aske qd thy thou wolt shall answer tho sayd thus whether wenest thou qd world gouerned foolishly hap fortune el wenest thou gouernement reason b certes qd ne trowe nat manner yt certain thing bee mooued fortunous fortune wote well god maker maister gouernour werk ne neuer yet day might put soothnesse sentence p qd shee ye thing sang thou little beforne bewailedest weptest onely men put cure god thing thou ne doubtest nat nere gouerued reason ough wonder certes greatly yt thou art sicke sen thou art put holsome sentence let v seeken deeper conjecte lacketh say sen thou ne doubtest yt world gouerned god gouernaile takest thou heed gouerned vnneth qd know ye sentence thy question ne may yet answeren thy demand deceiued qd yt ne failed somewhat ye maladie perturbation crept thy thought strength thy paleis shining open say remembrest thou wt ye end thing whider entention kind tendeth haue heard told time qd drerinesse hath dulled memorie certes qd thou wotest well whence thing comen proceden wote well qd aunswerde god beginning may qd ye sen thou knowest beginning thinges yt thou knowest nat ye end thinges suche beene ye customes perturbation power han yt may moue man place say stablenesse perfection knowing certes may nat al arace ne alien would yt thou woldest answere remembrest thou yt thou art man b remember yt qd phi mayst thou tell qd thing man asketh thou qd whether yt reasonable mortall beast wote well confesse wilt thou neuer yet thou thing qd qd well know qd cause thy malady right great thou hast left knowen thy selfe thou art haue plainly founden cause thy malady el entre recouering thy heale thou art confounded foryeting thy selfe thou sorowdest thou art exiled thy proper good thou ne wist end thing thy demest thou fellonous wicked men mightie welefull thou hast foryetten gouernments world gouerned thy wenest thou mutation fortune fleten without gouernour ben cause malady certes gret cause death thanke actour maker heale nature hath forleten thee haue great norishing thine heale sooth sentence gouernaunce world thou beleeuest gouerning subiect ne underput folly hap auenturous reason god therfore doubt thee nothing little sparke thine heat life shall shine much time yet faster remedy nature thought thus deceiued oft cast away sooth opinion clothen hem false opinion false opinion derkenesse perturbation wexeth confoundeth insight darknesse shall somewhat assay maken thinne weak light meaneliche remedy darkenesse deceyuing thing done away thou may know shining light nubibus atris condita nullum fundere possunt sidera lumen si mare voluens turbidus auster misceat estum vitrea dudum parque serenis c sterres couered black cloud ne mow yeten adowne light troubled wind hight auster turning wallowing sea medeleth heat saine boyling botome waues whylome clear glasse like faire bright dayes withstand anon sight men filth ordure resolued fleeting stream reileth doun diuersly high mountaignes arrested resisted oft time encounteriog stone departed fallen roch thy thou wilt looken deeme sooth cleare light holden way right path weiue thou ioy driue fro drede fleme thou hope ne let sorow approch saine let none foure passion ouercome blend thee cloudie derke thilke thought bound bridle thing reignen explicit liber primus post haec paulisper obticuit atque ubi attentionem meam modesta taciturnitate collegit sic exhorsa est si poeuitus egritudinis tuae causa habitumque c slint little gadered temper stylnesse mine attencion might saine thus thynges shee slint little apperceiued temper stilnesse ententiue hearen began speake wise qd haue understonden knowen utterly cause habite thy maladye thou languishest art defected desire talent thy rather fortune ilke fortune onely chaunged thou fainest thee ward hath peruerted clerenesse estate thy courage understonding felle manyfold colour deceit thilke maruailous monster fortune useth full flattering familiaritie hem enforceth beguile long till confound unsufferable sorrow hem hath left despaire unpurueyed thou remembrest well kind manner desert thilke fortune thou shalt well knowe thou neuer ne haddest ne haste yloste anie fayre thing trowe shall greatly trauailen done thee remembren thinges thou wont hurtelen despisen manly wordes blandishing present pursudest sentence drawen mine entre say mine enformacion suddaine mutacion ne betideth without manner chaunging courage befall thou art little departed fro peace thy thought time yt thou drinke atast soft delitable thing entered within thee mowen make way strenger drinkes medecines come forth therefore suasion sweetnesse rethorien goeth onely right way forsaketh mine estatutes rhetorike come forth musicke damosel house singeth lighter mood prolacions heauier eyleth thee man hath cast thee mourning weeping trow thou hast seen new thing uncouth thou wenest fortune chaunged ayen thou wenest wrong thou wene alway tho manner hath rather kept thee ward proper stablenesse changing selfe right flattered thee deceiued thee unleful liking aud false wilfulnesse thou hast knowen atteint doubtous double visage thilke blind goddesse fortune yet couereth wimpleth folke hath shewed selfe euery dele thee thou approuest thinkest good use manner plain thee nat thou agrisest false trecherie despise cast away plaieth harmfully cause much sorrow thee shuld thee cause peace ioy hath forsaken thee forsooth neuer man may siker ne shall forsaken glose nathelesse book haue text thus sooth hath forsaken thee ne ni man siker ne hath forsaken holdest thou thilk welefulnesse precious thee shall passen present fortune dere worth thee yt ni faithfull dwell goeth away bringeth wight sorow sen may bee withholden man maketh wretch departeth fro thing fleeting fortune manner shewing wretchednesse come ne suffiseth looken thing present eyen man wisdom looketh measureth end thing changing one another sain aduersitie prosperitie maketh menace fortune ne dreden ne flattering desired thus last hooueth suffren euell pacience done within floore fortune lay world sith thou half one put thy neck vnder yoke thou wolt writen law wending dwelling fortune thou hast chosen freely ben thy lady art thou nat wrongful makest fortune wroth asper thine impacience yet thou mayest nat chaungen thou committest betakest thy fails wind thou shalt shouen nat thider thou wouldest whider wind shoueth thee thou castest thy seed field thou shouldest haue mind yeares amongs plentuous whiie barrein thou hast betaken thy self gouernaunce fortune thy behooueth thee obeysant maners thy lady enforcest thou thee arresten withholden swiftnesse sweigh tourning wheel thou fool mortal fool fortune began dwell stable ceased ben fortune haec cum superba verterit vice dextra ex aestuantis fertur euripi dudum tremen do seva proterit reges humilemque victi sublevat fallax vultum non illa dura miseros audit haud curat flerus c fortune proud right hand withtourned chaunging stounds fareth like manner boiling euripe glosa euripe arme sea ebbeth floweth somtime streme side somtime text cruell fortune casseth adown king whylome ydrade deceiuable enhaunseth vp humble discomfited ne neither heareth ne recketh wretched weeping hard laugheth scorneth weeping hem hath maked weep free thus playeth thus proueth strength sheweth great wonder seruants wight seen welefull ouerthrowne houre vellem autem pauca tecum fortunae ipsius verbis agitare tu igitur jus postulet animadverte p quid tu homo ream agis quotidianis querelis c certes would pleaden thee thing vsing word fortune take heed nowe thy self ask right thou man wherefore makest thou giltie thine euery dayes plainings wrong haue done thee wt good haue beraft thee thine striue plete judge thou wilt possession riches dignity thou maiest shewen euer mortall manne hath receyued tho thing ben proper grant freely yt thilk thing thine thou askest nature brought thee forth thy mother womb receiued thee naked needie thing nourished thee riches ready ententife fauour sustain thee maketh thee impacient ayenst enuironned thee haboundance shining good right liketh withdraw mine hond thou hast grace hath vsed forraign good thou hast right plain thee though thou haddest vtterly forlorn thy thing plainest thou haue done thee wrong riches honour thing ben right seruants known lady come departen wend dare well affirm hardly tho thing thou plainest thou hast forlorn thine thou ne hadst forlorn hem shall defended vse right certes lefull heauen make clear day ouercome tho day derk night year hath eke leaue apparaile visage earth floures fruit confound hem sometime rain cold see hath eke right ben somtime caulm blandishing smooth water sometime horrible waues tempest couetise men yt may stanched shal bind stedfast sithen yt stedfastnesse vncouth manner strength play play commonly turn whirling wheele turning circle glad changen lowest highest highest lowest worth thou wolt law yt thou ne hold nat thee wrong though thou discend adown ye reason play asketh wost thou cresus king lidians king cyrus ful sore agast little beforne cresus caught cyrus ledde fire brend rain discended heauen rescowed mind paulus consul rome taken king perciens weped pitously captivitie ye self king thing bewaylen cry tragedy deed fortune yt aukward stroke ouertourneth realmes great nobley glose tragedie saine ditee prosperitie time endeth wretchednesse lernedest thou grece thou young entre seller iupiter ther ben couched two tonne one full good full harme right hast thou plaine thou hast taken plentuously good side sain richesse prosperite eke departed fro thee eke mutabilitie yeueth thee rightful cause hope haue yet better thing nathelesse dismay thee thy thought thou yt art put commune realm ne desire liuen thine proper right si quantas rapidis flatibus incitus pontus versat arena aut quot stellifei edita noctibus coelo sidera fulgent tantas fundat opes nec retrahat manum pleno copia cornu humanum miseras haud ideo genus cesset flere querelas c though plentie goddesse rich hylde downe full horne withdrawe hand many richesse see tourneth upward sand moued rauishing blast el many riches shinen bright sters heauen sterrie night yet mankinde nolde cease weepe wretched plaint god receyued prayer yeueth hem full large much gold apparaileth couetous folke noble clere honor yet seemeth haue gotten nothing alway cruel rauine deuouring haue gotten sheweth gapings say gapen desiren yet mo riches bridle might withholden certaine end disordinant couetie men euer rather fleteth large yefts brenneth hem lust hauing certes quaking dredefull weneth himselfe needy ne liueth neuermore rich igitur si pro se tecum verbis fortuna loqueretur quid profecto contrahisceres non haberes si quid est quo querelam tuam jure tuearis proferas oportet therefore fortune speak thee self manner forsooth thou ne hadst nat thou mightest answere thou hast thing wherewith thou mayest rightfully defenden thy complaint behooueth thee shewen woll yeuen thee space tellen boecius certainely qd faire thinges annoynted honey sweetnesse rhethorike musick heard sowne eares delicious wretch deeper felyng harme sayne wretch feelen harmes suffer greeuously remedy delight word may gladden conforten hem thinges stinten sown eares sorrow inset greueth ye thought p right doth qd ne yet remedy maladie manner nourishing thy sorrowes rebell ayenst thy curacion time shall moue ajust thing peircen hem full deep nathelesse thou shalt wilne leten thy self wretch hast thou foryeten number manner thy welefulnesse speak soueraign men citie tooke thee cure keeping thou orphelyn father mother chosen affinitie prince citie thou beganne rather lefe deare neyghbour thyng precious kind propinquitie alliaunce may ne sayed tho thou ne right welefull great nobley thy father law chastitie thy wife opportunity noblesse thy masculine child sayne thy sonnes ouer list passen common thing thou haddest thy youth dignity warned old men deliteth commen singular upheaping thy welefulnesse fruite mortal thynges may haue wight price welefulnesse mightest thou euer foryeten charge harme whiche might befall remembraunce thilke day thou saw thy two son made counsailours ladde together thy house great assemble senatours blithnesse people thou saw hem set court high chaires dignity thou rhetorien pronouncer king praisings deseruedest glory wit eloquence thou sitting thy two son counsaylours place hight circo fulfille dest bidding multitude people spradde thee large praysing laud men sing victory tho yaue thou fortune trowe say tho feoffedest thou fortune glorious word deceiue dest acoyed nourished thee delices thou bare away fortune yest say guerdon neuer yaue private man wilt thou therefore lay reckning fortune hath first twidckled vpon thee wicked eye thou consider number manner thy bliss thy sorows thou mayest nat forsaken nart yet blisful therfore thou wenest thy self welefull tho thing seemeden joyfull ben passed ni thou shouldest seem thy self wretch thing semed sorry passen also art thou commen suddain ghest shaddow tabernacle life trowest thou stedfastnesse man thing oft swift hour dissolueth man say soul departed body although selde faith fortunous thing would dwellen yet nathelesse last day man life manner death fortune also thike hath dwelt therefore wenest thou doth recke thou forlet dying el fortune forlete thee flyen away cum polo phebus roseis quadrigis lucem spergere caeperit pallet albentes hebetara vultus flammis stella permentibus c phebus sunne beginneth spreade clearenesse rosen charriots sterre dimmed paleth white cheres flame sunne ouer commeth sterre light sayne sunne risen daysterre wexeth pale leseth light great lightnesse sunne wood wexeth rodie rosen flour ye first summer season breath winde zepherus wexeth warme cloudie winde auster blowe fell liche goeth away fairenesse thornes oft see clere caulme mouing floodes oft horrible wind aquilon moueth boyling tempest ouer whelueth sea forme worlde selde stable turneth many enterchaunges wilt thou trusten tumblynge fortune men wilt thou trowen fleeting good certaine established law perdurable nothing engendred stedfast ne stable tum ego vera inquam commemoras virtutum omnium nutrix nec inficiati possum prosperitatis meae velocissimum cursum sed hoc est quid c saied thus nourice vertues thou sayest full sooth ne may forsake right swifte course prosperitye saine prosperitye ne commen woonder swiftly soone thing greatly smarteth remembreth aduersities fortune vnselie kind contrarious fortune haue welefull phi thou abiest thus qd yt tourment thy false opinion maist thou rightfully blamen ne aretten thing sayeth thou hast yet many haboundances thing textus idle name aduenturous welefulnesse moueth thee lefull thou recken many thynges thou hast yet plentie therfore yt thilk thing thou haddest precious thy richesse fortune kept thee yet grace god vnwemmed vndefouled mayest thou plaine rightfully vpon mischeefe fortune sithen thou hast yet thy best thinges certes yet liueth good point thilke precious honor mankind symachus thy wife father yt man made sapience vertue man thou wouldst buy price thine owne life bewayleth wrong men doen thee liueth sikernesse sentence put ayenst yet liueth thy wife attempre wit passing woman cleanenesse chastitie would close shortly hounties like father tell thee yt liueth loth life keepeth thee ghost mate ouercome weeping sorrow desire thee thing mote graunten thee yt thy welefulnesse amenused shall saine eke thy two son counsaylours child age shineth likenesse wit father elde father sithen souerain cure mortall folk sauen liues thou know thy self thy good make thee welefull yet ben thing dwelled thee ward man doubteth ne deereworth thee thine life thy drie tear yet euery fortune hatefull thee ward ne ouergreat tempest ne hath yet fallen vpon thee thine ankers cleven fast neither woll sufferen ye comfort time present ne hope time coming passen ne failen bo pray qd fast mote holden ye while holden howsoeuer thing shall well fleten forth escapen thou maist well seen great apparailes array lacked passed away fro phi haue somewhat aduanced furthered thee qd yt thou annoy forthink thy fortune saith haue somewhat comforted thee yt thou tempest thee thus thy fortune sithen thou hast yet thy best thyngs may fuffren thy delices plainest weeping anguishous lacketh somewhat thy welefulnesse man sad great perfite welefulnesse ne striueth playneth half ayen qualitie estate full anguishous thing ye condicion man good eyther commeth together wight el ne lasteth perpetuell man hath great richesse ashamed vngentill linage man renomed noblesse kinrede inclosed great anguish need thing yt leuer vnknow man haboundeth richesse noblesse yet bewayleth chast life ne hath wife man selily maried hath child nourisheth riches straunge folk man gladded child weepeth full sore trespace son doughter ne accordeth wight lightly yt condicion fortune alway euery man somwhat vnassayed ne wote nought el dreadeth hath assayed add also euery welefull man hath full delicate feeling thing befallen impacient vsed haue none aduersitie anon throwen adown euery little thing full little thing tho withdrawn summe perfection blisfulnesse fro hem fortunate many men trowest thou would deemen hemselfe ben almost heauen mighten attain least partie remenaunt thy fortune place thou cleapest exile countrey enhabiten thy nothing wretched thou wenest saith thou thy self ne wight el ni wretch weneth wretch reputation courage ayenward fortune blisful man agreeabilitie egalitie suffereth man weleful nold changen estate hath lost pacience sweetnesse man welefulnesse sprant many bitterness welefulnesse although seem sweet joyful vseth yet may withholden ne goeth away woll well seen wretched blisfulnesse mortal thing neither dureth perpetuel hem euery fortune receiuen agreeably egally ne deliteth hem ben anguishous ye mortal folk seek ye blisfulnesse self put self errour folly confoundeth shall shew thee shortly point soueraign blisfulnesse thing thee precious thy life thou wilt aunswere nay thou art mightie ouer thy self sain tranquilitie thy soul hast thou thing thy power thou noldest neuer lesen ne fortune may bynemme thee thou maist know blisfulnesse ne may stand thyngs fortunous temporell nowe vnderstande gather together thus blisfulnesse soueraign good nature liueth reason ne thilke thing soueraign good may taken away wise worthie thing dign thilke thing may taken away sheweth well vnstablenesse fortune may nat attayne receyue blisfulnesse yet moreouer manne tumbling welefulnesse leadeth eyther wote changeable el wote wote blisful fortune may blindnesse ignoraunce wote chaungeable mote alway ben adrad ne lese thing ne doubteth may lesen fayth mote alway agast least lese woteth right well may lese continuall dread hath ne suffereth welefull el lese weneth dispised foreleten certes eke full little good born euen hart lost sain men force losse hauing much thou thy self art hath shewed preued full many demonstration wote well soul men ne mowen dien wise eke sen cleare certain yt fortunous welefulnesse endeth death body may doubted death may take away blisfulnesse kind mortal thing ne descendeth wretchednesse end death sithen know well many man hath sought fruit blisfulnesse suffering death eke suffering pain tourments might present life make men blisfull sen thilk self life ended ne maketh folk wretch quisquis volet perennem cautus ponere sedem stabilisque nec sonori sterni flatibus euri et fluctibus minantem curat spernere pontum montis cacumen alti bibulas vitet arena c manner folk ware stable woll founden hem perdurable seat ne cast lowde blast wind eurus despise sea menasing floudes let eschew builden coppe mountain moist sand fell wind auster tormenteth coppe mountain strength lose sand refusen bear heauy weight thy thou wolt flien perillous aduenture say world haue mind certainly set thine house merrie seat low stone although wind troubling sea thunder ouerthrowing thou art put quiet welefull strength thy palleis shalt lead clear age scorning woodnesse ire aire sed quoniam rationum jam te mearum fomenta discendunt paulo validioribus utendum puto age enim si jam caduca ac momentaria fortunae c bvt much nourishings reason discenden thee trow time vsen little stronger medicine vnderstand yefts fortune ne brittle ne transitorie hem may thyne time el ne foul looked considered perfitly riches precious nature hemself el nature thee worth richesse gold might money assembled tertes gold money shineth yeueth better renome dispenden thilk folk muckeren auarice maketh alway muckerers ben hated largesse maketh folk clere renome sith thing ben transferred one man another ne may dwell man certes money precious translated folk stinten vsage large yeuing hath yeuen also money ouer world gadered toward one man make men needie certes voice hole yt sain without amenusing fulfilleth together hearing much folk ben apassed need maken hem poor forgone tho riches strait needy clepe riches sen yt many folk ne may haue ne ne may commen one man without pouertie folk shining gem call precious stone draweth eyen folk hemward sain beautie certes beautie bountie shining stone thilk clearnesse stone hemself men wonder greatly men maruailen thing thing wanteth moouing joyncture soule bodye right might seemen fair creature hath soul reason yt gem drawn hemself little last beautie world thentent creator distinction hemself yet mikel ben put vnder excellence ne haue deserued way ye maruailen hem beautie field delighteth mikell vnto b delighten v sith right fayre porcion right fayre werke sayne world right gladded sometime face sea clear also maruailen heauen starres sunne moone phi appertaineth qd thilk thing thee darest thou glorifie thee shining anye thyngs art thou distingued embelised springing floures first summer season swelleth thy plentie fruit summer art thou rauished idle joy embracest thou strange good thine fortune ne shall neuer make thing thine nature thing hath maked forrain fro thee sooth withouten doubt fruit yearth owen nourishing beast thou wolt fulfill thy need suffiseth nature need yt thou seek superfluitie fortune full thing full little thing nature hath apaid thou wolt achoken yt fulfilling nature superfluity certes thilke thing yt thou wolt thresten pouren nature shullen ben unjoyful thee el annoyous wenest thou eke yt fair thing shine diuers clothing clothing yt beauty agreeable looken vpon woll maruailen ye nature matter thilk clothes el workman wrought hem doth also long rout meine make thee blisfull man seruants ben vicious condicions great charge destruction hous great enemie ye sord ben good men shall strange forrain goodnesse put number thy riches foresaid thing clearly shewed neuer one thilk thing yt thou accomptedest thy good na thy good thing beautie desired shouldest thou sorrie lese shouldest thou rejoyce thee hold hem fair kind wt appertaineth yt thee also wel shoulden haue ben fair though departed thy riches fair ne precious commen among thy riches seemed fair precious therfore thou hadst leuer recken hem among thy riches desirest thou fortune great afare trow thou sekest driue away need abundance thing certes turneth contrarie certes needeth full many helping keepen ye diuersitie precious hostile ments sooth many thing haue need yt many thing haue ayenward little thing needeth measureth fill need kind outrage couetise ye menne haue proper good set ye moten seek outward forraine subject thing condicion thing tourned vp doun man yt diuine creature merit reason thinketh himselfe ni neither faire ne noble possession hostiliments ne han life certes al thing ben apaied beauty ye men semblable god reasonable thought desiren apparailen excellent kinde lowest thing ne ye vnderstanden howe great wrong done creatour would mankinde worthy noble yearthly thing ye thresten dignity beneathen lowest thing good every thing precious thilke thing whose good sith ye deemen foulest thyngs good submitten ye put selven vnder foulest thing estimation certes betideth without desert certes condition mankinde onely hath knowing selfe passeth noblesse thing forletteth knowing self brought beneathen beast liuing creature han kind knowen men letten knowing hemselfe commeth hem vice brode sheweth errour folly men yt wenen thing may ben apparailed straunge apparailements forsooth may done wight shineth thyngs put thus thilke thing shinen manne apparailed certes thilke thinges commended praised apparailed natheles thing covered wrapped vnder dwelleth filthe deny thilk thing good yt anoyeth yt hath gabbe thou wolt say nay certes riches haue annoyed full oft hem han tho richesse sith every wicked shrew wickednesse ye greedy folkes riches whersoever place gold precious stone weneth worthy hath hem thou yt busie dredest swerd spear thou haddest entred path life annoyen wayfaring men wouldest thou sing theef saith poore man beareth richesse ye way may boldly sing beforne theeves hath whereof robbed precious right clear blisfulness mortal richesse thou hast gotten hast thou lorne thy sikernesse foelix nimium prior aetas contenta fidelibus arvis nec inerti perdita luxu facilique serum solebat jejunia solvere glande nec bacchia munera norat liquido confundere melle nec lucida vellera serum c blisful first age men held hem apayed meat true field broughten forth ne destroyed deceived hemselfe outrage woont lightly slaken hunger even achornes okes ne coude medell yefte bacchus cleare honey sain could make ne piemente clarre ne could medell bright fleece countrey syrian venime tirie saine coude dyen white fleece syrian countrey blood manner shellfish men finden tyrie blood men dyen purple slepten holsome sleep vpon ye grasse dronken renning water lien vnder ye shadow ye high pine tree ne gheste straunger ne carfe yet ye high sea oares shippes ne ne hadden seine yet new stronds leaden marchandise diver countreys tho cruell clarion full hust full still ne blood ad eagre hate ne dyed yet armures whereto would woodnesse enemy first mouen armes sawen cruel wound ne none meedes blood yshad would time tourne ayen old manner anguishous loue folke burneth cruelly mountain ethna aye brenneth ala first dalfe gobbet weight gold couered earth precious stone woulden haue hid dalfe precious peril sain hem first dalfe dalfe precious peril preciousnesse thing hath many man ben peril quid autem de dignitatibus potentiaque disseram quas vos vere dignitatis ac potestatis inscii coelo exaequatis quae si improbissimum quemque ceciderint c bvt shall say dignity power yee men neyther knowen dignitie ne power areisen high heauen whiche dignity power commen wicked man doen great dammages destruction doth flame ye mountaine ethna ye flame walloweth ne deluvy ne doth cruel harm certes ye remember well trow yt thilke dignitie ye men cleape imperie counsaylours whylome beginning freedome elder coueited haue doen away pride counsailours right elder time done away citie rome king name sain nolde haue lenger king yt dignity power ben yeuen good men thing ful seld agreable thing tho dignity power onely goodnesse folke vsen hem therefore thus yt honour commeth vertue dignitie ayenward honour commeth dignitie cause vertue whiche thilke deereworth power cleare requirable yee yearthly creature consider yee ouer thing seemeth ye haue power thou saw mouse emong mouse challenged himselfeward right power ouer mouse great scorne wouldest thou haue glosa fareth men body hath power ouer ye body thou look well vpon body wight thyng shalt thou find frayle mankinde menne full oft bee slain biting fly el entring creeping wormes priuities man bodie shall men finden man may exercisen haunten right vpon another man body el vpon thyngs beene lower bodye whiche cleape fortune possession mayest thou haue euer commaundement ouer free courage maiest thou remeue fro state proper rest thought yt cleauing together himselfe stedfast reason whylome tyraunt wened confound free man courage wend constrayne tourments maken discoueren accusen folke wislen coniuracion clepe confederacie yt cast ayen tyraunt freeman hote owne tongue cast visage thilke wood tyraunt torment wood tyraunt wend haue made matter crueltie wise man made matter vertue wt thing man may doe another man yt ne may receiuen thing folke himselfe thus may man doen folke yt folke ne may doen haue heard tolde busiride woont slean ghestes harbouren house slaine himselfe hercules ghest regulus taken battaile many men affrick cast hem fetter soone must yeuen handes bee bound cheines hem whylome ouercommen wenest thou mightie hath power doen ne may doen doe yet moreouer yt dignity power hadden proper naturall goodnesse hem neuer nold commen shrewes contrarious thinges ne woont ifellowshipped togethers nature refuseth yt contrarious thing ben joyned certaine wicked folke haue dignity oft time sheweth well dignity power ne good owne kind sen sufferen hemself cleauen joynen hemself shrewes certaine thing may dignely judgen saine ye yefts fortune yt plenteously commen shrewes yefts trowe ought bee considred man doubteth hee strong seeth strength swiftnesse sooth swift also musick maketh musiciens phisicke maketh physiciens rhetoricke eke rhetoriciens nature euerie thing maketh property ne entermedled yt effect contrarious thyngs certes riches may restraine auarice vnstaunched ne power ne maketh man mightie ouer yt vicious lust holden
