distrained chain ne mowen vnbounden dignity yeuen shreud folke onely ne maketh hem digne sheweth rather openly vnworthy indigne thus certes yee haue joy clepe thing false name bearen hem contrary name ben full oft reprooued effect thinges ilke riches ne oughten right bee cleped riches ne power ne ought cleped power ne dignitie ne ought cleaped dignitie last may conclude thing yefts fortune ni nothing bee desired ne yt hath himselfe naturall bountie well iseene neither ioynen hem alway good men ne maken hem alway good joyned novimus quantas dederit ruinas urbe flammata patribusque caesis fratre qui quondam ferus interempto matris effuso maduit cruore corpus visu gelidum pererrans os non tinxit lachrimis sed esse censor extincti potuit decoris c well known many great harmes distructions doen emperour nero let brennen citee rome made slea senatours cruell whilome slough brother made moiste blood mother say let sleen slitten ye wombe mother seen conceyued loked euery halue dedde cold bodie ne teare wette face hard harted yt might dome man iudge dedde beautie nathelesse yet gouerned nero scepter people phebus may seen comming vtterest arising till hid beam vnder wawes yt saine gouerned ye people septre imperiall sunne goeth fro east west eke nero gouerned septre people vnder ye cold sterres highten septentrions sain gouerned people yt vnder ye party north eke nero gouerned people ye violent winde nothus skorclith baketh brenning sandes drie heate say ye people south yet ne might power tourne woodnesse wicked nero ala greuous fortune oft wicked sweard joyned cruell venime say venemous crueltie lordship tunc ego scis inquam ipsa minimam nobis ambitionem mortalium rerum fuisse dominatam sed materiam gerendis rebus optavimus quo ne virtu cacita consenesceret p et illa atqui hoc unum est c said thus thou wotest well thy selfe couetise mortall thinges ne hadden neuer lordship haue well desired matter thinges doen saith desire haue matter gouernaunces ouer comminalties vertue still elden saine lest er wext old vertue lay still ne perishe vnexercised gouernance commune men might speaken writen good gouernement phi forsooth qd thing may drawen gouernaunce soche harte worthy noble nature nathelesse may drawen tellen harte ybrought full perfection vertue sain couetise glorie renome haue well administred ye common thing doen good desertes profite ye common see consider little void price thilke glory certaine thing thou hast learned ye demonstracion astronomy al ye enuironning ye yearth ne halt reason pricke ye regard greatnesse ye heauen sain maked comparison yearth ye greatnesse heauen men would judgen ne held space ye little region world fourth part yearth inhabited liuing beast knowen thou hast thy selfe ilearned ptholome proueth thou haddest withdrawen abated thy thought thilke fourth part moch space see mary conteynen ouergone moch space ye region drought ouer stretcheth saine sand desertes wel vnneth shuld dwellen right strait place habitacion men ye enuironed closed lest pricke thilke pricke thinken ye manifesten publishen renome done name ben borne forth glory yt narow straight throngen litel bound mikell conteyneth large great also set thereto yt many nacion diuers tongue maners eke reason liuing inhabite close thilke habitacle ye nacions difficultie wayes diuersitie language defaulte vnusage entrecomming marchandise onely ye name singuler men ne may stretchen eke ye fame city may stretchen laste certes time marcus tullius selfe writeth boke renome ye commonwelth rome ne yet passed ne clomben ouer mountaine yt hight caucasus yet rome well waxen redoubted ye parthes eke folk enhabiting seest thou straite compressed thilke glory yee trauailen shewen multiply may glory singuler romane stretchen thider fame name rome may climben ne passen eke seest thou yt maners diuers folke lawes discordant amonges hemlelf yt thilke thing yt som men judge worthy praising folke judgen worthy tourment hereof commeth yt though man deliteth praysing renome may wise bringen forth ne spreden name many maner people therefore euery man ought apaid glory ye published among owne neighbour thilke noble renome shall restrayned within bound tho maner folke many man yt full noble tyme hath wretch nedy foryeting writer put mind away al yt certes thilke thing profiten litell thing writing long derke elde away hem eke auctours ye men semen getten perdurabilitie ye thinken time comming fame shall lasten nathelesse thou wilt make comparison endlesse space eternite wt thing hast thou thou maist rejoycen thee long lasting thy name made comparison ye abiding moment ten thousand winter moch tho space ben ended yet hath moment porcion although litell nathelesse thilke selfe nombre yeres eke many yeres thereto may multiplied ne may certes comparisoned ye perdurabilite yt endlesse thing yt ende may made comparison thinges withouten ende thing haue end may maked comparison thy although renome long time euer thee list thinken compared regard ye eternitie vnstaunchable infinite ne onely seem littell plainly right nought yee semen certes ye nothing right ye audience people ydle rumour ye forsaken great worthinesse conscience vertue ye seken guerdon small word strange folke haue vnderstand lightnesse soche pride veine glory man skorned festinally merily soche vanite whilom man yt assaied striuing word another manne usage vertue proude vaine glory taken upon falsly name philosophre rather man speak thought wold assay wheder thilke philosophre say yt would haue suffred lightly pacience wrong done fained philosophre toke pacience litel receiued word outrage striuing ayen reioysing self said last thus vnderstandest thou philosophre man answerde bitingly said well understand thou haddest holden thy tonge still wt noble worthy men certes folk speak seken glory vertue qd atteyneth fame soche folke body resolued deth last men dien say body soul thing reason defendeth u beleue glory wise wt thilke glory thilke glory said ni right naught wise ye soul hath self science good werkes unbounden prison ye yerth wendeth freely heauen dispiseth erthly occupacion heauen reioyseth exempt erthly thing faith recketh soul neuer glory renome world quicunque solam mente praecipiti petit summumque credit gloriam lace patentes aetheris cernat plagas artumque terrarum situm brevem replere non valentis ambitum c ouerthrowing thought onely seeketh glory fame weneth soueraine good let loken upon brode shewing countreys heauen upon straite seate earth shall ashamed thencrease name may fulfill littel compas earth coueyten proude folk liften neckes idle deadly yoke world although renome ysprad passing toforn people goth diuers tonges although great house kindred shinen clere title honour yet nathelesse death dispiseth high glory fame death wrappeth togithers high head lowe maketh equal euen hiest lowest wonen bone trew fabricius brutus sterne caton thynne fame yet lastyng ydle name marked letter although haue knowen fair word fame hem yeuen know hem deed consumpt liggeth still utterly unknowable ne fame ne maketh know ye wene liue ye lenger wind mortal name one cruel day shall take away also shall ye die second death first death clepeth departing body second death stinting renome fame sed ne inexorabile contra fortunam gerere bellum putes est aliquando cum de hominibus fallax illa non nihil bene mereatur tum scilicet cum se aperit c bvt moch thou shalt wenen qd beare untreatable batayle ayenst fortune yet sometimes falleth nothing disceiuable deserueth haue right good thanke men selfe openeth discouereth front sheweth manner perauenture yet understandest thou shall say wondre desire tell therefore vnneth may unpliten sentence word deme yt contrarious fortune profiteth men fortune debonayre alway fortune semeth debonayre lieth falsly biheting hope welefulnesse contrarious fortune alway sothfaste sheweth selfe unstable chaungyng amiable fortune disceiueth folk yt contrary fortune teacheth amiable fortune blindeth beautie false goodes hart folk usen hem contrary fortune unbindeth hem knowing frele welefulnesse thamyable fortune maiest thou sene alway windy flowing euer misknowing self contrary fortune attempre restrained wise thorow exercise aduersite last amiable fortune flaterings draweth miswandring men fro soueraine good contrarious fortune leadeth oft folk ayen sothfast good halteth hem ayen hoke wenest thou thou oughtest leten litell thing aspre horrible fortune hath discouered thee thought thy trew frendes ilke fortune hath departed uncouered thee certain visage eke doutous visage thy felawes departed away fro thee took away frends laft thee thy frendes thou rich welefull thee semed mykell woldest thou haue bought full knowing sain knowing thy frends plain thee richesse lorne sith thou haste found precious kind richesse saine thy frendes quod mundus stabili fide concordes variat vice quod pugnantia semina faedus perpetuum tenet c world stable faith varieth accordable chaungings contrarious qualitees element holden among hem self alyaunce perdurable phebus sonne golden chariot bringeth forth rosie day moon hathe commaundement ouer nightes nightes esperus euen sterre hath brought sea gredy flowen constraineth certain end flood lefull stretch brode term bound upon yearth ordinaunce thing bounden loue gouerneth earth sea also hath commaundement heauen loue slaked bridle thinges louen togithers wolden make bataile continuelly striuen fordone facion world leden accordable faith faire mouings loue holdeth togider people ioyned holy bond knitteth sacrament mariage chaste loues loue endeth lawes true felawes welefull mankinde thilke loue gouerneth heauen gouerned courage phere endeth second boke jam cantum illa finierat cum audiendi avidum stupentemque arrectis adhuc auribus carminis dulcedo defixerat itaque paulo post inquam summum lassorum solamen animorum quantum c ended song sweetnesse dytie perced mee desirous herkening astonied yet streight mine eares yt saine herken bet say yt litel said thus thou art souerain comfort corages anguishous thou hast remounted nourished ye weight thy sentence delite singing trowe unperegall stroke fortune saith dare well suffren thassauts fortune well defend tho remedy thou saidest beforne yt right sharpe agrisen hem desirous hearing ask greatly hearen ye remedy saied thus feled well qd thou ententife still rauishedest word abode till thou haddest soche habyte thy thought thou hast el till self maked habit trew thing certes ye remnant thing ben yet say ben soch yt first men taste hem bene biting bene receiued within wight ben swete thou sayst thou art desirous hearken hem great brenning wouldest thou glowen thou wiltes whider wold leden thee b whider qd p thilke blisfulnesse qd thine hart dremeth moch thy sight occupied distourbed earthly thing thou maiest yet sene thilk self welefulnesse b doe qd shew thilke welefulnes pray thee without taryeng p woll gladly done qd cause thee wol first marken word woll enforcen enforme thee thilk false cause blisfulnesse thou knowest thou haste beholden thilke false goodes turned thine iyen side thou may knowen eleerenesse blisfulnesse qui serere ingenuum volet agrum liberat arva prius fruticibus falce rubos filicemque resecat c woll sowe field plenteous let first deliueren thornes kerue asonder hoke bush ferne corne may commen heauie eres greines hony swete mouth haue first tasted sauors wycke sterres shinen agreably wind nothus letteth plungy blastes lucifer day sterre hath chased away dark night day fairer ledeth rosen horse sonne right thou beholding first false good begin withdraw thy neck fro yt yearthly affection afterwards good shullen entren thy corage tum defixo paululum visu velut angustam suae mentis sedem recepta sic cepit p omnis mortalium cura quam multiplicium studiorum labor exercet c tho fastened litel sight eien withdrew right strait seate thought began speake right thus cure qd mortall folke trauailen hem many maner study gon certes diuers wayes nathelesse enforcen hem commen onely thende blisfulnes blisfulnes soch good hath gotten ne may thing desire thing forsooth soueraine good conteyneth manner goodes good fayled thing might soueraine good good soueraine good might desired clere certaine blisfulnesse parfite state ye congregacion goodes ye blisfulnesse haue sayd mortal folke enforcen hem get diuers way couetise euery good naturelly planted ye hart men miswandring errour misledeth hem false good men hem wenen soueraine good liuen without need thing men demen soueraine good right digne reuerence enforcen hem reuerenced among neighbour honour haue gotten folk ben holden right hie power soueraine good enforcen hem reignen el ioynen hem hem reigne seemeth folk noblesse renome soueraine good hasten hem getten hem glorious name artes werre peace many folke measuren gessen souerayne good ioy gladnesse wenen bee right blisful thing plongen voluptuous delites ben folke enterchaungen cause end foresaid good desiren riches haue power delight el desire power haue money cause renome thing soch turned entencion desirings werkes menne thus noblesse fauour people yeueth men seemeth hem maner cleerenesse renome wife child men desiren cause delite merinesse forsoth frendes ne shullen rekened among goodes fortune vertue full holy maner thing thing forsoth taken cause power el cause delite certes ready referren good body foresaid thing abouen semeth strength greatnesse body yeuen power worthinesse beaute swiftnesse yeuen glory renome health body seemeth yeuen delite thing seemeth onely blisfulnesse desired thilke thing euery man desireth moste ouer thing deemeth soueraine good haue defined blisfulnesse souerain good euery wight deemeth thilke estate desireth ouer thing blisfulnesse hast thou thine eyen almost purposed forme welefulnesse mankind sain richesse honour power glory delites delite onely considred epicurus aud iudged established delite soueraine good moche thing thought byrest away ioy myrthe hart returne againe study men men corage alway reherseth seeketh soueraine good dyrked memory pathe right dronken man note nought path may returne home house semeth folke forleyen erren enforcen hem haue need nothing certes none thing may moch performen blisfulnesse estate plenteous good ne hath neede none thing suffisaunt himselfe unto folien soche folke wenen thilke thing right good eke right worthy honor reuerence certes nay thing ny neither foule ne worthy dispised well nigh entencion mortal folke travailen get power eke ought rekened amongs goodes el ni wene thilke thing worthy thing feble without strength clerenesse renome ought yt ben despised certes may man forsake thing yt right excellent noble ne semeth right clere renomed certes needeth say blisfulnesse anguishous ne drerie ne subject greuaunces ne sorowes sen right littell thing folke seken haue usen may delighten hem certes ben thing men willen desiren getten cause desiren riches dignity reignes glorie delites therby wened haue suffisaunce honour power renome gladnes good men seken thus many diuers study desire may lightly shewed great strength nature men haue diuers sentence discordings algates men accorden louing end good quantas rerum flectit habenas natura potens quibus immensum legibus orbem provida servet stringatque ligan irresoluto singula nexu placet arguto fidelibus lentis promere cantu c lyketh shew subtil song slack delitable sowne string nature mightely enclineth aud flitteth gouernment thing soche lawe shee purueiable keepeth great world binding restraineth thing bonde may unbounden lion countrey pene beren faire chaines taken meates hand folke yeuen hem dreden sturdie maisters wont suffre beating horrible mouthes bledde sain beestes devoured corage time passed hath idle rested repaireth ayen roren greuously remembren nature staken neck chaines unbound maister first torne bloody teeth assaieth woode wrathes hem sain fretten maister iangling bird singeth hie braunches saine woode enclosed straite cage although plyeng besinesse men yeue hem honied drinkes large meates swete study yet natheles thilke bird skipping straite cage seeth agreeable shadowes woodes defouleth foot meat ishad seeketh morning onely wood twireth desiring woode swete voise yerde tree haled adown mighty strength boweth redily croppe downe hand bent let gone anon croppe looketh vpright heauen sonne phebus falleth euen westren wawes returneth ayen eftsones carte priuy pathe wont arise thing seken ayen proper course al thing rejoysen returning againe nature ne none ordinance betaken thing hath joyned end beginning hath made course self stable chaunge fro proper kind vos quoque terrena animalia tenui licet imagine vestrum tamen principium somniatis verum que illum beatitudinis finem licet minime perspicaci c certes also ye men ben erthly creature dreamen alway beginning although thin imaginacion maner thought nat clerely ne perfectly ye loken ferre thilke fine blisfulnesse therefore naturel entencion leadeth thilke good many maner errours mistourneth therefro consider thilke thing man weneth get blisfulnesse may commen thilke end weneth come nature money honor foresaid thing bringen men soch thing good ne fail ne semeth fail certes wold graunt maked blisfull thing haue gotten thilke thing ne mowen performe byheten defaut many goodes sheweth clerely false beautie blisfulnesse knowen atteint thilk thing first forward thou thy self haddest aboundance richesse nat long agon ask thee thaboundance al thilk rich thou neuer anguishous sorrie thy courage wrong greuaunce betide thee side b certes qd ne remembreth euer free thought ne alway anguish somewhat p qd thee lacked somewhat thou noldest haue lacked el thou haddest thou noldest haue b right qd p desirest thou presence one thabsence b graunt well qd p forsoth qd nedeth somewhat euery man desireth b ye nedeth qd p certes qd hath lacke neede aught ni euery way suffisant b qd p thou qd al plentie thy richesse haddest thilke lacke suffisance b el qd p may rich maken man ni nedy ne sufficient yet beheten semed eke certes trowe greatly consider money hath owne kind ne may bynomen hem haue maugre hem bo know well qd p shouldst thou beknowen qd euery day strenger folke benomen feobler maugre hem whens come el forain complaint quarels pleading men asken money hath binomed hem strength gyle alway maugre hem boec right qd phi hath man need qd seeken forain help may defend money boecius may say nay qd phil certes qd needed helpe ne money might lese boecius doubtles qd philosophie thing tourned contrary qd richesse men wenen maken suffisaunce maken man rather haue need forain help maner guise qd richesse may driuen away need riche folke may neuer haue honger ne thurst rich men may fele cold lims winter thou wilt aunswere rich men haue inough wherewith may staunchen honger slaken thurst doen away colde wise may need comforted richesse certes need ne may vtterly doen away need alway gaping greedy fulfilled richesse thing yet dwelleth need mote fulfilled hold still tell little thing sufiseth nature certes auarice suffiseth inough nothing since rich ne may doen away need maken need wt may ye wenen riches mowen yeuen suffisaunce quamvis fluente dive auri gurgite non expleturas cogat avarus opes c al noble couetous man riuer gutter fleeting gold yet neuer staunch couetise although neck charged precious stone red sea though ere field plenteous hundred ox neuer ne shal biting businesse forleten liueth ne light riches ne shall bearen compaigny dead sed dignitatis honorabilem reverendum que cui provenerint reddunt num vi ea est magistratibus ut utentium mentibus vi tutes inserant vicia depellant c bvt dignity commen maken honourable reverent great strength may putten vertue hertes folkes usen lordship hem el may done away vice certes wont away wickednes wont rather shew wickednesse thereof commeth haue right great disdain dignity yeuen wicked men thing catullus cleped consull rome hight nonius postome boche saith cleped congregacion vice brest postome full corrupcion nonius set chaire dignite seest thou great vilonies dignity done wicked men certes unworthines wicked men shuld lasse seen nere renomed none honour certes thou thy selfe ne mightest bee brought many peril thou mightest suffre thou woldest beare magistrate decorate saine peril might befall thee offence king theodorike thou noldest felawe gouernaunce decorate thou sawe wicked corage licorous shrew accusour ne may soche honour iudgen hem worthy reuerence deeme holde unworthy haue thilke honour thou saw man fulfild wisdome certes thou ne mightest deme unworthy honour el wisedome whiche fulfilled boecius qd philosophie certes qd dignity appertainen properly vertue vertue transporteth dignitie anon thilke man selfe conioyned moch honour people ne may make folke digne honour well seen clerely ne haue proper beautie dignitie yet men oughten take heed wight moch outcast despised folke dignitie ne may maken shrewes worthy reuerence maketh dignite shrewes rather dispised praised shrewes dignite sheweth moche folke forsooth unpunished saine shrewes reuengen hem ayenward upon dignity yelden ayen dignity great guerdon dispotten defoulen dignity vilonie moch thou knowest thilke reuerence ne may nat commen shadowy transitorie dignity understonde thus man used many maner dignity consul parauenture commen among straunge nacions shuld thilke honour maken worshipfull redoubted straunge folke certes honour people naturel yefte dignity ne might neuer cessen among maner folke done office right fyre euery countrey ne stinteth enchaufen maken hote moch honorable reuerent ne commeth folk proper strength nature onely false opinion folk saine wenen dignity maken folke digne honour anone therefore commen folke ne knowen thilke dignity honour vanishen away anon among straunge folke mayst thou saine ne amongs hem borne ne dureth thilke dignity alway certes dignitie prouostry rome whilom great power nothing ydle name rent senatorie great charge wight whilom office taken hede vitailes people corne thinges holden amongs hem great thing caste thilke prouostrie haue said little beforne thilke thing hath proper beaute self receiueth sometime price shining sometime leseth thopinion usaunces dignity ne mowe make folke digne reuerence dignity wexen foule wyll silthe shrewes dignity lesen shining chaunging tymes wexen foule estimacion people han hem selfe beaute ought desired saith none ne mowen yeuen beaute dignite none quamvis se tyrio superbus ostro comeret niveis lapillis c al proude nero wode luxure kembe apparelled faire purpure tirie white peerles algates yet thereof hee hatefull folke say behated folkes yet wicked nero great lordshippe yafe whilome reuerent senatours unworshipful seates dignity vnworshipfull seates clepeth nero wicked yafe dignity would reasonably wenen blisfulnesse soch honour yeuen vicious shrewes vero regna regnumque familiaritas efficere potentem valent quidni c bvt reignes familiarity kynges may maken man ben mighty el blisfulnesse dureth perpetually certes olde age time passed eke present time full ensamples king haue chaunged wretchednesse welefulnes noble thing clere thing power ni founden mighty keepe selfe power realmes authour maker blisfulnesse thilk power lacketh side amenuseth nat thilke blisfulnesse bringeth wretchednesse yet al yt realmes mankinde stretchen brode yet mote need ben moch folke ouer euery king ne hath lordship ne commaundement certes vpon thilk side power falleth yt maketh folke blisfull right ye side powere entreth vnderneth maketh hem wretch maner moten king haue porcion wretchednesse welefulnesse tyraunt king cecile yt assayed ye perill essate shewed similitude ye dredes realmes gastenesse swerde hong ouer head familier thing power yt may done away bitings businesse ne eschew prickes drede certes yet woulden liuen sikernesse may nat yet glorifyen hem power holdest thou yt thilke man mighty yt thou seest would done yt may done holdest thou mighty man yt hath enuironned side men arm sergeant dredeth hem maketh agast dreden put ye hand seruaunts hee seeme mightie familiers seruaunts king tell thee thing sith selfe haue shewed thee realmes hemselfe ben ful great feeblesse familiers certes ye royall power kinges hole estate estate abated full oft throweth adowne nero constrayned senecke familier mayster chesen death would die antonius commanded yt knight slowen swerds papinian familier papinian beene long time full mightie amonges hem court yet certes woulden haue renounced power two seneck enforced himselfe yeuen nero richesse also haue gone solitarie exile ye great weight saine lord power fortune draweth hem shullen fall neyther hem ne might doe yt hee would thing thilk power though men yet ben agast thou wouldest haue thou nart siker thou wouldest forleten thou maiest nat eschewen wheder ben men friend need counsayled fortune vertue certes folk weleful fortune maketh frendes contrarious fortune maketh hem enemy pestilence mighty annoy wight familiar enemy qui se volet esse potentem animos domet ille feroces nec victa libidine colla c woll mightie mote daunten cruell courage ne put nat neck ouercommen vnder ye foule raynes lechery lordship stretch ferre yt country inde quaketh thy commandment thy law last isle yt see hight tyle thrall thee yet thou maiest nat putten away thy foule derke desire driuen fro thee wretched complaint certes ni power thou hast gloria vero quam fallax saepe quam turpis est unde non injuria tragicus exclamat gloria gloria millibus mortalium nihil aliud facta nisi aurium inflatio magna c glory deceiuable foule oft thynge vnskilfully tragedian yt saine maker dities yt highten tragedy cried said glory glory qd thou nart nothing el thousand folkes sweller eares many haue full great renome false opinion people thing may thought fouler suche praysing thilke folke praysed falsely moten needes haue shame praysing folke haue getten hem thank praising desert thing hath thilk prise eched encreased conscience wise folke measured good nat rumour ye people ye soothfastnesse conscience seme fair thing man haue encreased sprad name followeth yt deemed ben foule thing ne ysprad encreased said little yt sith mote needes many folkes folke renome man ne may nat commen befalleth thou wenest glorious renomed semeth next part erthes ben without glory without renome certes amongs thing ne trow nat prise grace people ni neither worthy ben remembred ne commeth wise judgement ne ferme perdurably name gentilesse man ne may well seene vaine flitting name gentilesse referred renome clereness linage gentil name forain thing say hem glorifien hem linage semeth gentilnes manner praising commeth desert auncesters praising maketh gentilnesse moten needes gentill ben praised thing followeth thou ne gentilnes thy self sain prise cometh thy desert forraine gentilnesse ne maketh thee nat gentill certes good gentilnesse trowe onely semeth manner necessite imposed gentilmen ne nat outragen forleauen fro vertues noble kinred omne hominum genus terris simili surgit ab hortu unus enim rerum pater est unus cuncta ministrat c al linage men earth semblable birth one alone father thing one alone ministreth thing yafe sun beames yafe moone horne yafe men earth yafe sterres heaven closed membres soules camen hie seat commen mortal folke noble seed noisen bosten ye elder ye loke beginning god father authour maker ny foreliued wight ungentill nourishe courage vnto vice forlete proper birth quid autem de corporis voluptatibus loquar quarum appetentia quidem plenum est anxietatis c shall sain delices body whiche delices desirings ben full anguish fulfillings hem ben full penaunce great sickness great sorrow unsufferable right maner fruit wickednes ben thilke delices wont bringen body folke yt usen hem delices joye may mouing wote well euer woll remembren luxures shall well understand issue delices ben sorowfull sory thilke delices mow make folke blisful cause moten beests ben cleped blisful beests entencion hasteth fulfill bodely jolitee gladnesse wife child honest thing hath said ouer mokell ayenst kind child founden tourmentours father many child biting euery condition needeth tellen thee hast er time assayed art yet anguishous time approve sentence disciple euripidis said hath child welefull infortune habet hoc voluptas omnis stimulis agit fruentes apiumque par volantium ubi gratia mella sudit fugit nimis tenaci ferit icta corda morsu c every delyte hath anguisheth hem prickes usen ressembleth flyeng flyes clepen bee hath shedde agreable honnyes flyeth away stingeth hertes hem smitten biting ouerlong holden nihil igitur dubium est quin hae ad beatitudinem viae devia quaedam sint nec perducere eo quenquam valeant c doubt way ne maner mistidings blisfulnesse ne ne mowen seden folk thider beheten leden hem great harm forsaid way ben enlaced shall shew shortly thou enforcest thee assemble money thou must byreuen money hath thou shinen dignity thou must besechen supplien hem yeuen tho dignity thou coueitest honour gone beforne folkes thou shalt defoule thy self thorow humblesse asking thou desirest power thou shalt awaits thy subiects anoyouslie cast many parils askest thou glory thou shalt distract aspre thinges thou shalt forgone sikernesse thou woldest leden thy life delites euery wight shal dispisen thee forleten thee thou art thrall thing yt right foule britel yt saine seruaunt thy bodie wel yseen litel brytel possession coueiten putten goodes body aboue owne reason mayst thou surmounten olifaunts greatnesse weight bodie mayst thou ben strenger ye bull mayst thou swifter tygre behold space stablenesse swift course heauen stint somtime wondren foul thing heauen certes ny nat rather thinges wondren upon reason gouerned shyning thy forme sayne beaute thy body swiftly passing transitorie certes flitting mutabilitie floures sommer season aristotel telleth men eyen beeste hight lynx loking folk might percen tho thinges withstond looked thentrailes body alcibiades full fayre superficie without seme right foule thy thou seemest fayre thy nature ne maketh nat disceiuaunce feblenesse eyen loken prayse good body moch euer thee list thou know algates saine goodes body thou wondrest upon may distroyed el dissolued heet feuer three day foresaid thing may reducen shortly summe worldly good ne mowen yeuen behighten ne parfite congregacion good yt ne ben way ne pathes bringen men blisfulnesse ne maken men blisfull heu heu quae miseros tramite devios abducit ignorantia non aurum viridi quaeritis arbore c ala foly ignorance misleadeth wandring wretch fro path good certes ye seken golde grene tree ne ye gadren precious stone vine ne hyden ginnes hie mountain catch fish ye may maken rich feests like hunte roe ye ne goe nat ford yt water hight thyrene ouer men know well crekes cauernes see yhyd floodes knowen eke water plenteous white perles knowen whiche water haboundeth reed purpure yt saine maner shelfish men dien purpure knowen strondes habounden tendre fish sharpe fish hight echines folkes suffren hemselfe ben blind yt hem ne retchen know thilke goodes ben yhid coueiten plungen hem yerth seken thilke good surmounteth heuen beareth ye sterres prayer may maken digne nice thoughtes men pray coueiten richesse honour haue gotten tho false good great trauaile therby mowen knowen goodes hactenus mendacis formam faelicitatis ostendisse sufficerit quod si perspicaciter intuearis ordo est deinceps c suffiseth haue said hyderto form false welefulnesse yt thou looke clerely ye order mine entencion requires hensforth wen ye welefulnes b forsoth qd see well suffisance may commen richesse ne power realmes ne reuerence dignity ne gentillesse glory ne joy delices p hast thou wel knowen ye cause qd b certes semeth qd ye see hem right though litel clifte leauer knowen hem openly thee phi certes qd ye reason al redy thilke thinge simply one thing without deuision yt errour folly mankinde devideth departeth misledeth transporteth parfit good goodes false vnparfit say wenest thou hath need power ne lacketh nothing boetius nay qd philos certes qd thou sayest aright yt thing yt partie febler power certes yt mote need needy foraine help boetius right qd philos suffisaunce power ben one kind boet semeth qd philosophie demest thou qd thing yt maner yt say suffisaunt mighty ought ben dispised el right digne reuerence aboue thing boet certes qd doubte right worthy reuerenced phil let v adden qd reuerence suffisaunce power demen thre thing one thing boetius certes qd let v adden graunt yt soth p demest thou qd yt derk thing noble yt suffisant reuerent mighty el right noble right clere celebrate renome consider qd haue graunted byforne ne hath need nothing mighty digne honour needeth clerenesse renome clerenesse hee might graunten himselfe lacke thilke clerenesse might semen febler side outcast glose say nay yt suffisaunt mighty reuerent clerenesse renome foloweth foresaid thinges hath ready suffisaunce boetius may qd deny mote graunten thing right celebrable clerenesse renome noblesse p followeth qd adden clerenesse renome ye foresaid thing amongs hem difference b consequence qd p thing qd ne hath nede foraine thing may thing strengthes noble honourable mery thing joyful boetius whence qd sorowe might come thing soche certes may thinke philosophie mote wee graunten qd shee thing ful gladnesse foresaid thing sothe certes also mote graunten suffisance power noblesse reuerence gladnesse onely diuers name substaunce hath diuersite boetius mote needly qd philosoph thilke thing qd one simple nature ye wickednesse men departeth deuideth enforcen hem getten partie thinge ne hath part ne getten hem neyther thilke partie ny none ne thing whole desire boetius manere qd philosophie thilke man qd secheth richesse flyen pouerty ne trauaileth get power hath leauer derke vyle eke withdraweth himselfe many naturell delytes hee nolde lese money hath assembled certes maner ne getteth suffisaunce power foreleteth molestie pricketh filthe maketh outcaste derkenesse hideth certes desireth power wasteth scattereth richesse despiseth delyces eke honour without power ne ne prayseth glory nothing certes seest thou well many thing faylen hath sometime defaute many necessitees many anguish byten hym may done tho defaltes away forletteth mighty thyng desyreth right thus may make semblable reason honour glory delices euery foresaid thing thing saine al one thing whosoeuer seketh getten one yt ne getteth desireth boetius sayest thou man coueite getten thing togider philoso certes qd wold say yt would get souerain blisfulnes yt shall finde tho thing haue shewed yt mowe yeue beheten boetius certes qd phi qd ne shullen men way seken blisfulnes soch thing men wenen ne mowe gyuen one thyng singlerly menne seken boetius graunt well qd ne non sother thing may said philosoph hast thou qd forme cause false welefulnesse turne flitte againe thy thought shall thou seene anon thilke blisfulnesse haue behight thee b certes qd clere open thogh blind man yt shewdest thou litel forne thou enforcedest thee shew cause ye false welefulnesse begiled yt thilke blisfulnesse parfite parfitly maketh man suffisaunt mighty honourable noble ful gladnesse thou shalt well knowe haue well vnderstanden thing within hart know well thilke blisfulnesse yt men verely yeuen one ye foresaid thing sen one know doubtlesse thilke thing full blisfulnesse philosophie norice qd opinion say thou art blisfull thou put thereto shall sain boetius qd ph trowest thou yt thing erthly mortall tombling thing yt may bringen estate bo certes qd trow thou hast shewed wel yt ouer thilk good ni nothing ben desired p thing qd yt saine earthly suffisaunce power soch thing erthly semen likenesse good el seemeth yeuen mortall folke maner goodnesse ne parfite thilke good parfite may yeuen boe accord well qd phil qd moch thou haste knowen thilke blisfulnes eke thilke thing ben yt lien falsely blisfulnesse say yt deceite semen goodes behoueth thee knowe whence thou mow seke thilke blisfulnesse b certes qd yt desire greatly haue abyden longe tyme herken p moch qd liketh disciple plato book tymeo right littell thing men shoulden beseche ye help god judgest thou yt done wee may deserue find ye seat thilke souerein god b certes qd denie yt shullen cleape father goodes withouten ny nothing founded aright p thou saiest aright qd began anon singen right thus qui perpetua mundum ratione gubernas terrarum caelique sator qui tempus ab aevo ire jubes stabilis que manens dans cuncta moveri quem non externae pepulerunt fingere causae c thou father soueraigne creatour heauen erthes gouernest world pardurable reason commandest time gone sith age beginning thou dwellest thy selfe aye stedfast stable yeuest al thing meued ne foryeue cause ne cesseden thee neuer compoun werke flattering mater onely forme souerain good yset within thee without enuy meued thee frely thou art alder fayrest hearing fayre world thy thought formedest world thy likenesse semblable fayre world thy thought thou drawest thing thy soueraine ensampler commaundest world perfetlich ymaked haue freely absolute perfite party thou bindest element nombres proporcionables cold thinges mowen accorden hotte thinges drie thing moist fire purest ne flie nat ouer hie ne heauinesse ne draw nat adoun ouerlow yerthes yt plonged water thou knittest togider ye meane soul treble kind mouing thing deuidest membres according thus deuided hath assembled amouing roundes goeth turne againe enuironneth full deepe thought turneth heuen semblable image thou euen lyke cause enhancest soules lesse liues abling hem height light waines carte thou sowest hem heauen yerth conuerted thee thy benigne law thou makest hem returne ayen thee ayen ledyng fyre father yeue thou yt thought styen vp thy straite seate graunt hem enuironne wel good ye light yfound graunt sixen ye clere sight courage thee scatter thou breake ye weyghts cloud earthly heauinesse shine thou thy brightnesse thou art clerenesse thou art pesyble rest debonayre folk thou thy selfe art beginning bearer leder path terme look thee end quoniam igitur quae sit imperfecti quae etiam perfecti boni forma vidisti nunc demonstrandum reor c forasmoche thou hast seen forme good ny parfite forme good parfite trow yt good shew perfection blisfulnes set thing trow shall first enquire weten soch maner good thilke good thou hast diffinished litell beforne saine soueraine good may found nature thing vaine imagination thought ne desceue v put v sothefastnesse thylke thyng yt submitted v may denied thilke ne right well goodes thing cleped imparfite proued imparfite ye amenusing perfection thinge parfite hereof commeth euery thing generall men sene thing imparfite certes thilke thinge generall mote thing parfite yt perfection away men may thinke ne say whence thilke thing cleped imparfite nature ne toke beginning thinges amenused imparfite procedeth thinges hole absolute discendeth ye vttrest thing thing empty without fruite haue shewed little beforne blisfulness freele vain imperfite may man doubt ni blisfulnesse sad stedfast parfite boecius concluded qd firmely soothfastly phi consider also qd blisfulnesse inhabiteth commune accord conceit courage men proueth graunteth god prince thing good nothing may thought better good may doubted yt nothing ny better ny good certes reason sheweth god good proveth force perfite good god ni ne may ben prince al thing certes thing possessing self perfite good worthy god seemen thilke thing first older god haue shewed apertly thing ben parfite first thing ben imparfite thy forasmuch reason processe ne go way without end owen granten soueraigne good right full soueraign perfit good established soueraign good blisfulnes mote need blisfulnes set soveraigne good boecius take well qd ne ne may withsaid manner philos pray thee qd see thou mayest proven holily withouten corrupcion sayd soueraign god full right soueraigne good bo manner qd phil wenest thou aught qd father thing hath taken thilke soveraigne good soueraigne good men proueth full right thou mightest thinken god hath blisfulnes thilk blisfulnese diver substance thou wene god hath received thilke good himselfe thou mayest wene yaue thilke good god worthy god beknow confesse right dignely god right worthy thing good nature diverse wening reason sen speaken god prince thing faine whoso faine may conioined thing together eke last see well thing yt diver fro thing thilke thing ni thing vnderstanden ben diuers followeth well thilke thing yt nature diver soueraigne good thing soueraigne good certes felonous cursednesse thinken nothing ni worth alway thing name hem ne may ben better beginner may concluden right reason thilke beginning thing thilke thing soueraigne god substance bo thou hast said rightfully qd pholos graunted qd soueraigne good blisfulnesse bo sooth qd philos qd mote need graunten confessen ilke soueraigne good god boe certes qd ne may deny ne withstande reason purposed see well followeth strength premiss philos look qd proved yet firmely thus ne mowen two soueraigne good ben diverse among hemselfe certes good diverse among hemselfe one ne mowen neither hem perfite either hem lacketh ni perfite men may seene apertly ni soveraigne thing yt soveraignly good ne mowen way diver well concluded blisfulnesse god soueraigne good mote need soveraigne blisfulnesse sovereign dignity boe nothing qd soothfast ne firme reason ne worthy thing god may concluded philoso vpon thing qd right geometrician shewed proposition wont bringen thing yt clepen porrismes declaration foresaid thing right woll yeue thee corollary mede crowne much getting blisfulnesse men maked blisful blisfulnesse dignity manifest open getting dignity men ben maked blisful right getting iustice yt getting sapience maked wise right need semblable reason haue gotten diuinitie made god every man blisful god certes nature ni one god participation diuinity ne letteth ne distourbeth nothing ne many god bo qd fair thing precious clepe thou wilt corollary porrisme mede croune declaring p certes qd nothing ni fairer thing reason shuld added foresaid thing bo thing qd ph qd seemeth blisfulnesse containeth many thing weten whether thing maken conioynen manner body blisfulnesse diversity party member else thing accomplish himselfe substaunce blisfulnesse thing referred brought blisfulnesse say cheef hem bo would qd thou madest clearly understand thou sayest thou recordest foresaid thing phi judged qd blisfulnesse good boe yes forsooth qd soueraigne good phi adde qd thilke good made blisfulnesse foresaid thing thilke blisfulnesse deemed soueraign suffisaunce thilke selfe soueraigne power soueraigne reuerence soveraigne clearenesse noblesse soueraigne delite sayst thou thing say suffisaunce power thing member blisfulnesse referred brought soueraigne good right thing brought cheef hem bo understond well qd thou purposest seek desire hearken thou shew ph take thus discretion question qd thing qd member felicitie diver one nature party member diver member compounen body bo certes qd hath well ben shewed beforne thing ben one thing phi member qd el seem blisfulnesse comoyned member alone thing may done bo thing qd ni doubtous abide hearken remenaunt thy question open cleare qd thing ben referred brought good therefore suffisaunce required deemed good thy power required men trowen also good thing mowen thinken conjecten reuerence noblesse delite soueraigne good summe cause ought desired thilke thing withholdeth good self ne semblaunce good ne may well manner desired ne required contrary though thing nature ne ben good algates men wenen good yet ben desired though verely good therefore said men ought wene right bounty soueraigne fine cause thing ben requiren certes thilke cause men requiren thing seemeth thilke thing desired thus wight would riden cause heale ne desireth much mooving riden effect heale sen thing ben required grace good ne ben desired folke good graunted blisfulnesse thing thing ben desired thus certes onely blisfulnesse required desired thing sheweth clerely good blisfulnesse one substance bo see qd wherefore men might discorden philos shewed god blisfulnesse one thing bo sooth qd phi mow conclude sikerly substaunce god set thilke good none place huc omnes pariter venite capti quos fallax ligat improbis catenis terrenas habitans libido mentes hic erit vobis requies laborum c commeth together ye ycaught bound wicked chain delite earthly thing inhabiting thought shall rest labour stable quiete pesible alone open refute wretch sain ye combred deceiued worldly affection commeth soveraine good god refute hem willen commen thing river tagus yeueth golden gravel el thing river hermus yeueth red brink indus yeueth next hote partie world medleth green stone white ne cleren looking thouyt hiden rather blind corage within derknes liketh exciteth moueth thought earth hath nourished within low caues shining heaven governed whence strength escheweth dark ouerthrowing soul whosoever may knowen thilke light blisfulnesse saine white beam sunne ne cleare assentior inquam cuncta enim firmissimis nexa rationibus constant tum illa quanti inquit tu aestimabis si bonum ipsum quid sit agnoveris c boecius assent qd thing ben strongly bounden right ferme reason philosophie much wilt thou praisen qd thou knowest like good boecius woll praise qd price without end shall betide know also togither god good philosophie certes qd shall doe thee reason tho thing concluded little beforne dwellen onely graunting boecius dwellen graunted thee qd saine saith graunt thy foresaied conclusion philosophie haue shewed thee qd thing required many folke ne good ne perfite ben diuers one hem lacking ne haue power bring good full absolute erst good gathered togider one forme one werking thilke thing suffisaunt thilke power reuerence noblesse mirth forsooth thing al one thing ne haue whereby mowe put ye number thing ought required desired bo shewen qd ne hereof may man doubten philosophie thynges qd ne goodes ben diuers beginnen one thing ben good ne commeth getting unitie maked good boeci seemeth qd philoso thyng good qd grauntest thou good participation good boecius grant qd philoso must thou graunten qd semblable reason one good one thing thing effect ni naturally diuers nedes substaunce must one thing boecius ne may denie qd philosophie hast thou knowen wel qd thing hath long dwelling sustaunce long one forletteth one must need dien corrumpen together boecius manner qd philoso right beast qd soule bodie conioyned one dwelling together cleped beast unitie destroyed thy disceueraunce one sheweth well dead thing lenger beast bodie wight dwelleth one forme coniunction member well seene figure mankind party bodie diuided disceuered one destroy unitie bodie forletteth beforne would ren manner thing seen without doubt euery thing substance long one forletteth one dieth perisheth bo consider qd many thing see none philosophie thing qd much liueth naturally foreletteth talent appetite desireth come death corrupcion boe consider qd beastes haue manner nature willing nilling ne find beast constrained fro withoutforth foreletteth despiseth entencion liuen duren thankes hasten dien euery beast trauaileth desende keep saluacion life escheweth death destruction certes doubt herbes tree ne haue feling soules ne natural working seruing appetite beast haue whether haue appetite dwellen duren philosophie certes qd thereof dare thee doubt looke upon ye hearbes tree wexen first place conuenable hem whiche place mowe dien ne drien long nature may defend hem hem wexen field wexen mountaines wexe mareis cleauen rock wexen plenteous sondes wight enforce bear hem place wexen drye nature yeueth euery thing conuenient hem trauayleth ne die long haue power dwellen liuen wilt thou sain yt drawen nouryshings root right hadden mouth yplunged within earthes shedden mareis wood barke wilt thou saine ilke thing right soft marie alway hid seat within defended without stedfastnesse wood utterest bark put ayenst yt distemperaunce heauen defendour mightie sufferen harme thus certes mayest thou well seene great diligence nature thing renouelen publishen hem seed ymultiplied ne ni man ne wote well ne right foundement edifice duren onely time right dure perdurably generacion ye thing eke yt men wenen ne haue soul ne desire semblable reason keep yt saine yt according nature conseruacion enduring wherefore el beareth lightnesse flame vp weight presseth yearth adoun much thilke place thilke mouings couenable eueriche hem forsooth euery thing keepeth thilke according proper right thing ben contrarious enemy corrumpen hem yet hard thing stone cleauen holden party togither right fast hard defenden hem withstanding ne departen lightly yeuen place hem breaken deuiden hem nathelesse retourne ayen soone thing whence araced fire fleeth refuseth deuision ne ne treat wilful moouings soule knowing naturell entencion thing thus right swallowen meat receiuen ne think draw breath sleeping sleepen certes beast loue liuings ne being ne commeth w nings soule beginning nature certes constrayning cause desireth embraceth full oft time death nature dredeth saine thus man may constrayned cause desireth taketh death nature hateth dreadeth full sore sometime seen contrary thus wight disturbeth constraineth nature alway desireth requireth say werkes generacion generacion dwelleth sustayned long durabilitie mortal thing thus charitie loue euery thing hath ne commeth mouing soul entencion nature purueyaunce god hath yeuen thing ben create full great cause liuen duren desiren naturelly life long euer mowen thou maist dreaden manner thing ne requiren naturally firm stablenesse perdurable dwelling eke eschewing destruction boeci confesse qd see well certainely withouten doubt thing ago seemeden vncertain philos qd thilk thing desireth dwell perdurably desireth one one destroyed certes none dwellen wight boecius sooth qd philosophie qd desiren thing one boecius assent qd philosophie haue shewed qd ilke one thilke good boecius ye forsooth qd philosophie thing qd requiren good thilke maist thou discriuen thus good thilke thing euery wight desireth boecius ne may thought thing qd either thing referred brought nought flotten without gouernour dispoiled one proper head el thing thing tenden hyen thing must soueraign good good philosophie said thus nourice qd haue great gladnesse thee thou hast fixed thy hart middle soothfastnesse saine pricke thing hath discouered thee thou saidest thou wistest little beforne boecius qd philos thou ne wistest qd end thing certes thing euery wight desireth much haue gathered comprehended good thilk thing desired mote need confesse good fine thing quisquis profunda mente vestigat verum cupitque nullis ille deviis falli se revolvat intimi lucem visus c seeketh sooth deep thought coueiteth beene disceyued miswayes let rollen treaten within himselfe light inward sight let gatheren ayen enclyning compace long moouinges thought let teachen courage hee hath enclosed hidde treasours hath compassed sought without thilke thing blacke cloudes errour whylome couered shall light clearely phebus himselfe ne shineth glosa woll seeke deepe ground sooth thought woll deceyued false proposicions gone amisse troth let well examine rolle within himselfe nature property thing let eftsoons examine rollen thought good deliberacion deme let teachen soul hath naturell principle kindliche thidde within self trouth ye imagineth thing without darknesse misknowing shall seme euidently sight vnderstanding sun ne semeth sight withoutforth certes bodie bringing weight foryeting ne hath chased thought clerenesse knowing certainly seed sooth holdeth cleaueth within corage awaked excited wind blast doctrine wherefore el deemen ye ye right ye asked nourishing reason ne liued yplunged deep heart sain men demen sooth thing asked nere root soothfastnesse yplunged hid naturel principle soothfastnesse liued within deepnesse thought muse doctrine plato singeth footh euery wight learneth ne doeth nothing el recordeth men recorden thyngs ben foryetten tum ego platoni inquam vehementer assentior nam horum jam secundo commemoras primum quod memoriam corporea contagione c said thus accord greatly plato thou recordest remembrest thyngs yet second time say first left memory contrarious conjunction body soule eftsoones afterward lost confounded thy charge burden sorrow sayed thus thou look qd first thyngs thou hast graunted ne shall right ferre thou ne shalt remembren ilke thing thou saidest thou nistest bo thing qd philos ye gouernment qd world governed bo remember well qd confesse well ne wist naught see afarre thou purposest algates desire yet hearken thee plainly phil thou ne wendest qd little beforne ye men dout world governed god bo certes qd ne yet ne dout ne nill neuer wene dout saith wot well god gouerneth world shall answeren thee reason brought world qd many diver contrarious party ne might never ben assembled forme one conioyned many diver thing diversitie nature discorden one fro must departen vnioynen thing conioyned ne one contained hath conioyned ybound ne certaine order nature ne bring forth ordeyne mouings place time dooings space quality ne one aye stedfast dwelling ordained disposed diversity moouings thilke thing whatsoeuer thing ymaked ladde clepe god word used folk phil said sith thou felest thus thing trow little doen thou mighty welefulnesse hole sound ne see eftsoones thy country let u looken thing purposed beforne numbred said qd suffisaunce blisfulnesse accorded god ilke blisfulnesse bo yes forsooth qd philos gouern world qd ne shall neuer haue need none help fro without el need help ne full suffisaunce boet yes thus mote need qd philos ordeyned himselfe alone thing qd boet may denied qd philos haue shewed god good bo remembreth well qd philosoph ordeyneth thing thilke good qd sith han accorded good gouerneth thing himselfe key steire edifice world kept stable without corrumping bo accord greatly qd haue apperceived little beforne thou wouldest say thus thinne suspection phi trow well qd trow thou leadest ententifely thine eye looken good natheles thing shall tell thee yet ne sheweth lasse token bo qd phil men trow qd rightfully god gouerneth thing key goodnesse thing haue taught thee hasten hem natural contencion come good may man doubten ne gouerned voluntarily ne conuerten hem good ordeynour ben according enclining gouernour king bo mote need qd realme ne seme blisful yoke misdrawings diver party ne sauing obedient thing ne phi nothing qd keepeth nature enforceth gone ayenst god boet qd philos thing enforced withstande god might avaylen last ayen haue graunted almighty right blisfulnesse certes qd utterly ne might auayle philos nothing qd either may withstand soveraigne god bo trow qd philos qd thilke soueraigne god thing gouerneth strongly ordayneth hem softely boetius said thus delite qd onely end summe reason thou hast concluded proued thilke word thou usest deliten much last fooles sometime renden great thyngs oughten ashamed hemselfe sain fooles reprehenden wickedly thinges touchen god gouernaunce oughten ashamed selfe sayed god refuseth onely werkes men ne entermeteth phi thou hast well heard qd fable poet gyaunts assaileden heauen god forsooth debonaire force god disposed hem worthy sain destroyed gyaunts worthy wilt thou rejoynen together thilk reason perauenture conjunction may sterten vp fair spark sooth boecius qd thee list philosophy wenest thou qd god ne almighty boecius man doubt certes qd philosophy wight ne doubteth mind qd almighty ni nothing ne may boecius sooth qd philosophy may god euil qd boe nay forsoth qd phi euil nothing qd sith may doen none euil may doen thing boecius scornest thou qd el playest thou deceiuest thou hast wonnen thy reason house dedalus enterlacing vnable vnlaced thou otherwhile enterest thou issuest otherwhile issuest thou enterest ne foldest thou togither replicacion word manner wonderful circle enuironning simplicity diuine certes little beforne thou began blisfulnesse thou saidest souerain good god blisfulnesse thou yaue couenable yeft sain wight ni blisful god also therewith saidest eke form good substance god blisfulnesse saidest thilke one thilk good required desired kind thing thou prouedst disputing god gouerneth thing world gouernance bounty saidest thing would obeyen saidest nature euil nothing thing shewedst thou reason taken fro without prooues cercles homeliche knowing prooues drawen hemself faith accord eueriche hem philosophy said thus ne scorn ne play ne deceiue thee haue shewed thing greatest ouer thing yeft god whylom praiden form diuine substaunce ne slideth vtterest forrain thing ne receyueth straunge thing right permenides said greek thilk diuine substaunce said thus thilk diuine substaunce tourneth world moouable cercle thing ilke diuine substaunce kepeth self without moouings saine mooueth neuer mo yet moueth thing nathelesse haue styred reason taken fro without compasse thing treaten reason ben bestowed within compasse ni thou shouldest meruaylen sith thou hast learned sentence plato needes wordes mote cosins thing speaken felix qui potuit boni fontem visere lucidum felix qui potuit gravis c blessed man may seene clere well good blisfull may vnbinden bound heauy earth poet thrace orpheus whylom right great sorrow death wife maked constrayned weepely song wood mouable renne maked riuers stonden still maked hart hindes
